<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-New_York_City skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">New York City</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Redirect4&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Redirect4 (page does not exist)">Template:Redirect4</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-protected&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-protected (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-protected</a>
{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
</p><p><b>New York</b> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population" title="List of United States cities by population">most populous city</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> and the center of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area" title="New York metropolitan area">New York metropolitan area</a>, one of the most populous <a href="/wiki/Urban_agglomeration" title="Urban agglomeration">urban agglomerations</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
The city is referred to as <b>New York City</b> or the <b>City of New York</b> to distinguish it from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York (page does not exist)">State of New York</a>, of which it is a part.
A <a href="/wiki/Global_city" title="Global city">global power city</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
New York exerts a significant impact upon commerce, finance, media, art, fashion, research, technology, education, and entertainment. The home of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">United Nations Headquarters</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
New York is an important center for international diplomacy<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
and has been described as the cultural capital of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-culture1_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-culture1-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-culture4_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-culture4-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>On <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">one of the world's largest natural harbors</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
New York City consists of five <a href="/w/index.php?title=Borough_(New_York_City)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Borough (New York City) (page does not exist)">boroughs</a>, each of which is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_counties_in_New_York" title="List of counties in New York">county of New York State</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
The five boroughs—<a href="/wiki/The_Bronx" title="The Bronx">The Bronx</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">Queens</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a>—were consolidated into a single city in 1898.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
With a census-estimated 2012 population of 8,336,697<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
distributed over a land area of just <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-census-est-nyc-ny_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-est-nyc-ny-11">[11]</a></sup>
New York is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_United_States_cities_by_population_density&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of United States cities by population density (page does not exist)">most densely populated</a> major city in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-density_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-density-12">[12]</a></sup>
As many as 800 languages are spoken in New York,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-800source2_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-800source2-14">[14]</a></sup> making it the most linguistically diverse city in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
By 2012 census estimates, the New York Metropolitan Area's population remains by a significant margin the United States' largest <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Metropolitan_Statistical_Areas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Metropolitan Statistical Areas (page does not exist)">Metropolitan Statistical Area</a>, with approximately 19.8&#160;million people,<sup id="cite_ref-2012metroest_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012metroest-16">[16]</a></sup> and is also part of the most populous <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Combined_Statistical_Areas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Combined Statistical Areas (page does not exist)">Combined Statistical Area</a> in the United States, containing an estimated 23.4&#160;million people.<sup id="cite_ref-2012combinedest_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012combinedest-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York traces its roots to its 1624 founding as a trading post by colonists of the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Republic" title="Dutch Republic">Dutch Republic</a> and was named <a href="/wiki/New_Amsterdam" title="New Amsterdam">New Amsterdam</a> in 1626.<sup id="cite_ref-u-s-history.com_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-u-s-history.com-18">[18]</a></sup>
The city and its surroundings came under English control in 1664<sup id="cite_ref-u-s-history.com_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-u-s-history.com-18">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
New York served as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_capitals_in_the_United_States#Former_national_capitals" title="List of capitals in the United States">capital of the United States</a> from 1785 until 1790.<sup id="cite_ref-senate_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-senate-21">[21]</a></sup>
It has been the country's largest city since 1790.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
The <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a> greeted millions of immigrants as they came to America by ship in the late 19th and early 20th centuries<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
and is a globally recognized symbol of the United States and its democracy.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many districts and landmarks in New York City have become well known to its approximately 55 million annual visitors.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> Several sources have ranked New York the most photographed city in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a>, iconified as "The Crossroads of the World",<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
is the brightly illuminated hub of the <a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">Broadway theatre</a> district,<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
one of the world's busiest pedestrian intersections,<sup id="cite_ref-Joshua_Pramis_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Joshua_Pramis-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
and a major center of the world's entertainment industry.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
The names of many of the city's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bridges_and_tunnels_in_New_York_City&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bridges and tunnels in New York City (page does not exist)">bridges</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tallest_buildings_in_New_York_City&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tallest buildings in New York City (page does not exist)">skyscrapers</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
and <a href="/wiki/List_of_New_York_City_parks" title="List of New York City parks">parks</a> are known around the world. New York City's financial district, anchored by <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a>, has been called the world's leading financial center<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>
and is home to the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">New York Stock Exchange</a>, the world's largest stock exchange by total <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a> of its listed companies.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
Manhattan's real estate market is among the most expensive in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Manhattan" title="Chinatown, Manhattan">Manhattan's Chinatown</a> incorporates the highest concentration of Chinese people in the Western Hemisphere.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
Providing continuous 24/7 service,<sup id="cite_ref-twentyfour_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-twentyfour-41">[41]</a></sup>
the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">New York City Subway</a> is one of the most extensive <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rapid_transit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rapid transit (page does not exist)">rapid transit</a> systems worldwide. Numerous colleges and universities are in New York,<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
including <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York University (page does not exist)">New York University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_University" title="Rockefeller University">Rockefeller University</a>, which have been ranked among the top 35 in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_era" title="Pre-Columbian era">precolonial era</a>, the area of present day New York City was inhabited by various bands of <a href="/wiki/Algonquian_peoples" title="Algonquian peoples">Algonquian</a> tribes of <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">Native Americans</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Lenape" title="Lenape">Lenape</a>, whose homeland, known as <a href="/wiki/Lenapehoking" title="Lenapehoking">Lenapehoking</a>, included Staten Island, the western portion of <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a> (including the area that would become Brooklyn and Queens), Manhattan, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lower_Hudson_Valley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lower Hudson Valley (page does not exist)">Lower Hudson Valley</a>, including The Bronx.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first documented visit by a European was in 1524 by <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_da_Verrazzano" title="Giovanni da Verrazzano">Giovanni da Verrazzano</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">Florentine</a> explorer in the service of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=French_crown&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="French crown (page does not exist)">French crown</a>, who sailed his ship <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=La_Dauphine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="La Dauphine (page does not exist)">La Dauphine</a></i> into <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a>. He claimed the area for France and named it "Nouvelle Angoulême" (<a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Angoul%C3%AAme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Angoulême (page does not exist)">New Angoulême</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-rodgers_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rodgers-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png" title="File:The Purchase of Manhattan Island.png">File:The Purchase of Manhattan Island.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Peter_Minuit" title="Peter Minuit">Peter Minuit</a> is credited with the purchase of the island of Manhattan in 1626.</div></div></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish</a> expedition led by captain <a href="/w/index.php?title=Est%C3%AAv%C3%A3o_Gomes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Estêvão Gomes (page does not exist)">Estêvão Gomes</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> sailing for <a href="/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor">Emperor Charles V</a>, arrived in <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a> in January 1525 aboard the purpose-built caravel "La Anunciada" and charted the mouth of the Hudson river, which he named <i>Rio de San Antonio</i>. Heavy ice kept him from further exploration, and he returned to <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> in August. The first scientific map to show the North American East coast continuously, the 1527 world map known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Padr%C3%B3n_Real&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Padrón Real (page does not exist)">Padrón Real</a>, was informed by Gomes' expedition, and labeled the <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_United_States" title="Northeastern United States">Northeast</a> as <i>Tierra de Esteban Gómez</i> in his honor.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1609, <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English people (page does not exist)">English</a> explorer <a href="/wiki/Henry_Hudson" title="Henry Hudson">Henry Hudson</a> re-discovered the region when he sailed his ship the <i><a href="/wiki/Halve_Maen" title="Halve Maen">Halve Maen</a></i> ("Half Moon" in Dutch) into New York Harbor while searching for the <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Passage" title="Northwest Passage">Northwest Passage</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Orient" title="Orient">Orient</a> for his employer the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a>. He proceeded to sail up what he named the <i><a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">North River</a>,</i> also called the <i>Mauritis River</i>, and now known as the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>, to the site of the present-day New York State capital of <a href="/wiki/Albany,_New_York" title="Albany, New York">Albany</a> in the belief that it might represent an oceanic <a href="/wiki/Tributary" title="Tributary">tributary</a>. When the river narrowed and was no longer <a href="/wiki/Saline_water" title="Saline water">saline</a>, he realized it wasn't a sea passage and sailed back downriver. He made a ten-day exploration of the area and claimed the region for his employer. In 1614 the area between <a href="/wiki/Cape_Cod" title="Cape Cod">Cape Cod</a> and <a href="/wiki/Delaware_Bay" title="Delaware Bay">Delaware Bay</a> would be claimed by the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> and called <i>Nieuw-Nederland</i> (<a href="/wiki/New_Netherland" title="New Netherland">New Netherland</a>).
</p><p>The first recorded non-<a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">Native American</a> inhabitant of what would eventually become New York City was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominican_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominican people (page does not exist)">Dominican</a> trader <a href="/w/index.php?title=Juan_(Jan)_Rodriguez&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Juan (Jan) Rodriguez (page does not exist)">Juan Rodriguez</a> (transliterated to Dutch as Jan Rodrigues). Born in <a href="/wiki/Santo_Domingo" title="Santo Domingo">Santo Domingo</a> of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=African_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African people (page does not exist)">African</a> descent, he arrived in <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> during the winter of 1613–1614, trapping for pelts and trading with the local population as a representative of the Dutch. <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(New_York_City)" title="Broadway (New York City)">Broadway</a>, from 159th Street to 218th Street, is named Juan Rodriguez Way in his honor.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg" title="File:GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg">File:GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/New_Amsterdam" title="New Amsterdam">New Amsterdam</a>, centered in the eventual <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a>, in 1664, the year <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> took control and renamed it "New York".</div></div></div>
<p>A permanent European presence in New Netherland began in 1624 with the founding of a Dutch <a href="/wiki/Fur_trade" title="Fur trade">fur trading</a> settlement on Governors Island. In 1625 construction was started on a citadel and a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Amsterdam_(New_Amsterdam)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Amsterdam (New Amsterdam) (page does not exist)">Fort Amsterdam</a> on Manhattan Island, later called New Amsterdam (<i>Nieuw Amsterdam</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Tolerance_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tolerance-50">[50]</a></sup> The colony of New Amsterdam was centered at the site which would  eventually become Lower Manhattan. The location of Dutch colonial Director-General <a href="/wiki/Peter_Minuit" title="Peter Minuit">Peter Minuit</a> purchased the island of Manhattan from the <i>Canarsie</i>, a small band of the <a href="/wiki/Lenape" title="Lenape">Lenape</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> in 1626 for a value of 60 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dutch_guilder&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dutch guilder (page does not exist)">guilders</a><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>  (about $1000 in 2006);<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
a disproved legend says that Manhattan was purchased for $24 worth of glass beads.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1664, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Stuyvesant" title="Peter Stuyvesant">Peter Stuyvesant</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Director-General_of_New_Amsterdam" title="Director-General of New Amsterdam" class="mw-redirect">Director-General</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Colony" title="Colony">colony</a> of <a href="/wiki/New_Netherland" title="New Netherland">New Netherland</a>, surrendered New Amsterdam to the English without bloodshed. The English promptly renamed the fledgling city "New York" after the <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_II_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James II of England (page does not exist)">Duke of York (later King James II)</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> At the end of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Anglo-Dutch_War" title="Second Anglo-Dutch War">Second Anglo-Dutch War</a>, the English gained New Amsterdam (New York) in North America in exchange for Dutch control of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Run_(island)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Run (island) (page does not exist)">Run</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesian</a> island. Several intertribal wars among the Native Americans and some <a href="/wiki/Epidemic" title="Epidemic">epidemics</a> brought on by contact with the Europeans caused sizable population losses for the Lenape between the years 1660 and 1670.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> By 1700, the Lenape population had diminished to 200.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1702, the city lost 10% of its population to <a href="/wiki/Yellow_fever" title="Yellow fever">yellow fever</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> New York suffered seven major <a href="/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_New_York_City_crimes_and_disasters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Timeline of New York City crimes and disasters (page does not exist)">yellow fever epidemics</a> from 1702 to 1800.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York grew in importance as a trading port while under <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British rule</a> in the early 1700s. It also became a center of <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">slavery</a>, with 42% of households holding slaves by 1730, more than any other city other than <a href="/wiki/Charleston,_South_Carolina" title="Charleston, South Carolina">Charleston, South Carolina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> Most slaveholders held a few or several domestic slaves, but others hired them out to work at labor.  Slavery became integrally tied to New York's economy through the labor of slaves throughout the port, and the banks and shipping tied to the South. Discovery of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=African_Burying_Ground&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African Burying Ground (page does not exist)">African Burying Ground</a> in the 1990s during construction of a new federal courthouse near <a href="/w/index.php?title=Foley_Square&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Foley Square (page does not exist)">Foley Square</a> revealed that tens of thousands of Africans had been buried in the area in the colonial years.
</p><p>The trial in Manhattan of <a href="/wiki/John_Peter_Zenger" title="John Peter Zenger">John Peter Zenger</a> in 1735 helped to establish the <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a> in North America. In 1754, <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> was founded under charter by <a href="/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain" title="George II of Great Britain">King George II</a> as King's College in Lower Manhattan.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Stamp_Act_Congress" title="Stamp Act Congress">Stamp Act Congress</a> met in New York in October 1765 as the <a href="/wiki/Sons_of_Liberty" title="Sons of Liberty">Sons of Liberty</a> organized in the city, skirmishing over the next ten years with British troops stationed there.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BattleofLongisland.jpg" title="File:BattleofLongisland.jpg">File:BattleofLongisland.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Long_Island" title="Battle of Long Island">Battle of Long Island</a>, the largest battle of the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>, took place in <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a> in 1776.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Long_Island" title="Battle of Long Island">Battle of Long Island</a>, the largest battle of the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a>, was fought in August 1776 entirely within the modern-day borough of Brooklyn. After the battle, in which the Americans were defeated, leaving subsequent smaller <a href="/w/index.php?title=Engagement_(military)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Engagement (military) (page does not exist)">armed engagements</a> following in its wake, the city became the British military and political base of operations in North America. The city was a haven for <a href="/wiki/Loyalist_(American_Revolution)" title="Loyalist (American Revolution)">Loyalist</a> refugees, as well as escaped slaves who joined the British lines for freedom newly promised by the Crown for all fighters. As many as 10,000 escaped slaves crowded into the city during the British occupation. When the British forces <a href="/w/index.php?title=Evacuation_Day_(New_York)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Evacuation Day (New York) (page does not exist)">evacuated</a> at the close of the war in 1783 they transported 3,000 <a href="/wiki/Freedmen" title="Freedmen" class="mw-redirect">freedmen</a> for resettlement in <a href="/wiki/Nova_Scotia" title="Nova Scotia">Nova Scotia</a>. They resettled other freedmen in England and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caribbean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caribbean (page does not exist)">Caribbean</a>.
</p><p>The only attempt at a peaceful solution to the war took place at the <a href="/wiki/Conference_House" title="Conference House">Conference House</a> on Staten Island between American <a href="/wiki/Delegate" title="Delegate">delegates</a> including <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a>, and British general <a href="/wiki/Lord_Howe" title="Lord Howe" class="mw-redirect">Lord Howe</a> on September 11, 1776. Shortly after the British occupation began the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Fire_of_New_York_(1776)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Fire of New York (1776) (page does not exist)">Great Fire of New York</a> occurred, a large conflagration which destroyed about a quarter of the buildings in the city, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trinity_Church_(New_York_City)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trinity Church (New York City) (page does not exist)">Trinity Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1785, the assembly of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Congress_of_the_Confederation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Congress of the Confederation (page does not exist)">Congress of the Confederation</a> made New York the national capital shortly after the war. New York was the last capital of the U.S. under the <a href="/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation" title="Articles of Confederation">Articles of Confederation</a> and the first capital under the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" title="United States Constitution">Constitution of the United States</a>. In 1789 the first President of the United States, <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a>, was inaugurated; the first <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">United States Congress</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court of the United States</a> each assembled for the first time, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Bill_of_Rights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Bill of Rights (page does not exist)">United States Bill of Rights</a> was drafted, all at <a href="/wiki/Federal_Hall" title="Federal Hall">Federal Hall</a> on Wall Street.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> By 1790, New York had surpassed <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a> as the largest city in the United States.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg" title="File:Hippolyte Sebron - Rue De New-York En 1840.jpg">File:Hippolyte Sebron - Rue De New-York En 1840.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Broadway_(New_York_City)" title="Broadway (New York City)">Broadway</a> follows the Native American Wickquasgeck Trail through Manhattan.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Under New York State's "Gradual <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abolition_of_slavery_in_the_USA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abolition of slavery in the USA (page does not exist)">Abolition</a> law of 1799", children of slave mothers were born to be eventually liberated but were held in <a href="/wiki/Indentured_servitude" title="Indentured servitude" class="mw-redirect">indentured servitude</a> until their mid-to-late twenties.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Together with slaves freed by their masters after the Revolutionary War and escaped slaves, gradually a significant free-black population developed in Manhattan. Under such influential <a href="/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States" title="Founding Fathers of the United States">United States founders</a> as <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Jay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Jay (page does not exist)">John Jay</a> the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_Manumission_Society&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York Manumission Society (page does not exist)">New York Manumission Society</a> worked for abolition and established the <a href="/w/index.php?title=African_Free_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African Free School (page does not exist)">African Free School</a> to educate black children.<sup id="cite_ref-Divided_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Divided-67">[67]</a></sup> It was not until 1827 that slavery was completely abolished in the state, and free blacks struggled afterward with discrimination. New York interracial abolitionist activism continued; among its leaders were graduates of the African Free School. The city's black population reached more than 16,000 in 1840.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 19th century, the city was transformed by development relating to its status as a trading center, as well as by European <a href="/w/index.php?title=Immigration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Immigration (page does not exist)">immigration</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> The city adopted the <a href="/wiki/Commissioners%27_Plan_of_1811" title="Commissioners' Plan of 1811">Commissioners' Plan of 1811</a>, which expanded the city <a href="/wiki/Grid_plan#Early_United_States" title="Grid plan">street grid</a> to encompass all of Manhattan.  The 1819 opening of the <a href="/wiki/Erie_Canal" title="Erie Canal">Erie Canal</a> through central New York connected the Atlantic port to the agricultural markets and commodities of the North American interior via the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> Local politics became dominated by  <a href="/wiki/Tammany_Hall" title="Tammany Hall">Tammany Hall</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Political_machine" title="Political machine">political machine</a> supported by Irish and German immigrants.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several prominent American literary figures lived in New York during the 1830s and 1840s, including <a href="/wiki/William_Cullen_Bryant" title="William Cullen Bryant">William Cullen Bryant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Washington_Irving" title="Washington Irving">Washington Irving</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herman_Melville" title="Herman Melville">Herman Melville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rufus_Wilmot_Griswold" title="Rufus Wilmot Griswold">Rufus Wilmot Griswold</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Keese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Keese (page does not exist)">John Keese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nathaniel_Parker_Willis" title="Nathaniel Parker Willis">Nathaniel Parker Willis</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Allan_Poe" title="Edgar Allan Poe">Edgar Allan Poe</a>. Public-minded members of the old merchant elite lobbied for the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>, which in 1857 became the first landscaped park in an American city.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_history">Modern history</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg" title="File:Mulberry Street NYC c1900 LOC 3g04637u edit.jpg">File:Mulberry Street NYC c1900 LOC 3g04637u edit.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Little_Italy,_Manhattan" title="Little Italy, Manhattan">Little Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lower_East_Side" title="Lower East Side">Lower East Side</a>, circa 1900.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Famine_(Ireland)" title="Great Famine (Ireland)">Great Irish Famine</a> brought a large influx of <a href="/wiki/Irish_diaspora" title="Irish diaspora">Irish immigrants</a>, and by 1860, one in four New Yorkers—over 200,000—had been born in <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> There was also extensive immigration from the German provinces, where revolutions had disrupted societies, and Germans comprised another 25% of New York's population by 1860.<sup id="cite_ref-Harris_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democratic Party</a> candidates were consistently elected to local office, increasing the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. In 1861 Mayor <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Wood" title="Fernando Wood">Fernando Wood</a> called on the aldermen to declare independence from Albany and the United States after the South seceded, but his proposal was not acted on.<sup id="cite_ref-Divided_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Divided-67">[67]</a></sup> Anger at new <a href="/w/index.php?title=Military_conscription&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Military conscription (page does not exist)">military conscription</a> laws during the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a> (1861–1865) led to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_Draft_Riots&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York Draft Riots (page does not exist)">Draft Riots of 1863</a>, led by ethnic Irish working class.<sup id="cite_ref-Divided_67-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Divided-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>The situation deteriorated into attacks on black New Yorkers and their property, following fierce competition for a decade between immigrants and blacks for work. Rioters burned the Colored Orphan Asylum to the ground, but its more than 200 children escaped harm.<sup id="cite_ref-Harris_73-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-73">[73]</a></sup> Rioters killed an estimated 100 blacks and attacked many more, especially in the docks area. It was one of the worst incidents of civil unrest in American history.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> Because of the violence, many blacks left the city for Williamsburg, Brooklyn and New Jersey; the black population in Manhattan fell below 10,000 by 1865, which it had last been in 1820. The white working class had established dominance.<sup id="cite_ref-Harris_73-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg" title="File:Old timer structural worker2.jpg">File:Old timer structural worker2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/wiki/Construction_worker" title="Construction worker">construction worker</a> on top of the <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a> as it was being built in 1930. The <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Building" title="Chrysler Building">Chrysler Building</a> is below and behind him.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1898, the modern City of New York was formed with the consolidation of Brooklyn (until then a separate city), the County of New York (which then included parts of the Bronx), the County of Richmond, and the western portion of the County of Queens.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> The opening of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">subway</a> in 1904, first built as separate private systems, helped bind the new city together. Throughout the first half of the 20th century, the city became a world center for industry, commerce, and communication.
</p><p>In 1904, the steamship <i><a href="/wiki/PS_General_Slocum" title="PS General Slocum">General Slocum</a></i> caught fire in the East River, killing 1,021 people on board.  In 1911, the <a href="/wiki/Triangle_Shirtwaist_Factory_fire" title="Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire">Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire</a>, the city's worst industrial disaster, took the lives of 146 garment workers and spurred the growth of the <a href="/wiki/International_Ladies%27_Garment_Workers%27_Union" title="International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union">International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union</a> and major improvements in factory safety standards.<sup id="cite_ref-cornell1_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cornell1-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York's non-white population was 36,620 in 1890.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> In the 1920s, New York City was a prime destination for African Americans during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American)" title="Great Migration (African American)">Great Migration</a> from the American South. By 1916, New York City was home to the largest urban African diaspora in North America. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Harlem_Renaissance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Harlem Renaissance (page does not exist)">Harlem Renaissance</a> of literary and cultural life flourished during the era of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prohibition_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prohibition in the United States (page does not exist)">Prohibition</a>.  The larger economic boom generated construction of competing skyscrapers that changed the skyline into its identifiable twentieth-century shape.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Stonewall_Inn_New_York_002.JPG" title="File:Stonewall Inn New York 002.JPG">File:Stonewall Inn New York 002.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_Inn" title="Stonewall Inn">Stonewall Inn</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>, a designated <a href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark" title="National Historic Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a> as the site of the 1969 <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_Riots" title="Stonewall Riots" class="mw-redirect">Stonewall Riots</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New York became the most populous urbanized area in the world in early 1920s, overtaking <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>.  The metropolitan area surpassed the 10 million mark in early 1930s, becoming the first <a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacity</a> in human history.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> The difficult years of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Great Depression</a> saw the election of reformer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fiorello_La_Guardia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fiorello La Guardia (page does not exist)">Fiorello La Guardia</a> as mayor and the fall of <a href="/wiki/Tammany_Hall" title="Tammany Hall">Tammany Hall</a> after eighty years of political dominance.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>Returning <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> veterans created a postwar economic boom and the development of large <a href="/wiki/Housing_tract" title="Housing tract" class="mw-redirect">housing tracts</a> in eastern Queens. New York emerged from the war unscathed as the leading city of the world, with Wall Street leading America's place as the world's dominant economic power. The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">United Nations Headquarters</a> (completed in 1950) emphasized New York's political influence, and the rise of <a href="/wiki/Abstract_expressionism" title="Abstract expressionism">abstract expressionism</a> in the city precipitated New York's displacement of <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a> as the center of the art world.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1960s, job losses due to industrial restructuring caused New York City to suffer from economic problems and rising crime rates, which extended into the 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> While a resurgence in the financial industry greatly improved the city's economic health in the 1980s, New York's crime rate continued to increase through the decade and into the beginning of the 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> By the 1990s, crime rates started to drop dramatically due to revised police strategies, improving economic opportunities, <a href="/wiki/Gentrification" title="Gentrification">gentrification</a>, and new residents, both American transplants and new immigrants from Asia and Latin America. Important new sectors, such as <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Alley" title="Silicon Alley">Silicon Alley</a>, emerged in the city's economy.  New York's population reached all-time highs in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Census,_2000&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Census, 2000 (page does not exist)">2000 Census</a> and then again in the 2010 Census.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg" title="File:UA Flight 175 hits WTC south tower 9-11 edit.jpeg">File:UA Flight 175 hits WTC south tower 9-11 edit.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">United Airlines Flight 175 hits the South Tower of the former <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Trade_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Trade Center (page does not exist)">World Trade Center</a> on September 11, 2001.</div></div></div>
<p>The city and surrounding area suffered the bulk of the economic damage and largest loss of human life in the aftermath of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=September_11,_2001_attacks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="September 11, 2001 attacks (page does not exist)">September 11, 2001 attacks</a> on the United States.  2,978 people died as a result of the terrorist attack on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Trade_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Trade Center (page does not exist)">World Trade Center</a> and many more were injured in the disaster.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup><a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_site#Rebuilding" title="World Trade Center site">The rebuilding of the area</a>, has created a new <a href="/w/index.php?title=One_World_Trade_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="One World Trade Center (page does not exist)">One World Trade Center</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/National_September_11_Memorial_%26_Museum" title="National September 11 Memorial &amp; Museum">9/11 memorial and museum</a> along with other new buildings and infrastructure which are at various stages of construction.<sup id="cite_ref-nypost-ap1_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nypost-ap1-85">[85]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Trade_Center_(PATH_station)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Trade Center (PATH station) (page does not exist)">World Trade Center PATH station</a>, which opened on July 19, 1909 as the Hudson Terminal, was also destroyed in the attack. A temporary station was built and opened on November 23, 2003.  A permanent station, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Trade_Center_Transportation_Hub&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Trade Center Transportation Hub (page does not exist)">World Trade Center Transportation Hub</a>, is currently under construction.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> The new One World Trade Center is the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_the_world" title="List of tallest buildings in the world">third-tallest building in the world</a> by <a href="/wiki/Pinnacle" title="Pinnacle">pinnacle</a> height, with its <a href="/wiki/Spire" title="Spire">spire</a> reaching a symbolic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in reference to the year of <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">American independence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Aster_newyorkcity_lrg.jpg" title="File:Aster newyorkcity lrg.jpg">File:Aster newyorkcity lrg.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Satellite_imagery" title="Satellite imagery">Satellite imagery</a> illustrating the core of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_City_Metropolitan_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York City Metropolitan Area (page does not exist)">New York City Metropolitan Area</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>New York City is in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northeastern_United_States_(U.S._Census_Bureau)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northeastern United States (U.S. Census Bureau) (page does not exist)">Northeastern United States</a>, in southeastern New York State, approximately halfway between <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boston&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boston (page does not exist)">Boston</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> The location at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>, which feeds into a naturally sheltered harbor and then into the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, has helped the city grow in significance as a trading <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">port</a>. Much of New York is built on the three islands of Manhattan, Staten Island, and <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>, making land scarce and encouraging a high population density.
</p><p>The Hudson River flows through the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Valley" title="Hudson Valley">Hudson Valley</a> into <a href="/wiki/New_York_Bay" title="New York Bay">New York Bay</a>. Between New York City and <a href="/wiki/Troy,_New_York" title="Troy, New York">Troy, New York</a>, the river is an <a href="/wiki/Estuary" title="Estuary">estuary</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> The Hudson separates the city from <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>. The <a href="/wiki/East_River" title="East River">East River</a>—a tidal strait—flows from <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_Sound" title="Long Island Sound">Long Island Sound</a> and separates the Bronx and Manhattan from Long Island. The <a href="/wiki/Harlem_River" title="Harlem River">Harlem River</a>, another tidal strait between the East and Hudson Rivers, separates most of Manhattan from the Bronx. The <a href="/wiki/Bronx_River" title="Bronx River">Bronx River</a>, which flows through the Bronx and <a href="/wiki/Westchester_County" title="Westchester County" class="mw-redirect">Westchester County</a>, is the only entirely <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">fresh water</a> river in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city's land has been altered substantially by human intervention, with considerable <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">land reclamation</a> along the waterfronts since Dutch colonial times. <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">Reclamation</a> is most prominent in <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a>, with developments such as <a href="/wiki/Battery_Park_City" title="Battery Park City">Battery Park City</a> in the 1970s and 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-gillespie-p71_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gillespie-p71-95">[95]</a></sup> Some of the natural relief in topography has been evened out, especially in Manhattan.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city's total area is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of this is water and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> is land.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_Land_Estimate_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_Land_Estimate-97">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYT_Land_Estimate_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_Land_Estimate-98">[98]</a></sup>
The highest point in the city is <a href="/wiki/Todt_Hill" title="Todt Hill">Todt Hill</a> on Staten Island, which, at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Above_mean_sea_level&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Above mean sea level (page does not exist)">above sea level</a>, is the highest point on the Eastern Seaboard south of <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">Maine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> The summit of the ridge is mostly covered in woodlands as part of the <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Greenbelt" title="Staten Island Greenbelt">Staten Island Greenbelt</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG" title="File:Hurricane Sandy Flooding Avenue C 2012.JPG">File:Hurricane Sandy Flooding Avenue C 2012.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Avenue_C_(Manhattan)" title="Avenue C (Manhattan)">Avenue C</a> in Manhattan after flooding caused by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hurricane_Sandy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hurricane Sandy (page does not exist)">Hurricane Sandy</a> on October 29, 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Under the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a>, using the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> coldest month (January) <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isotherm_(contour_line)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isotherm (contour line) (page does not exist)">isotherm</a>, New York City itself experiences a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Humid_subtropical_climate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Humid subtropical climate (page does not exist)">humid subtropical climate</a> (<i>Cfa</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-Peel.2C_M._C..3B_Finlayson.2C_B._L..3B_McMahon.2C_T._A_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Peel.2C_M._C..3B_Finlayson.2C_B._L..3B_McMahon.2C_T._A-102">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-newyorkpolonia.com_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newyorkpolonia.com-103">[103]</a></sup> and New York is thus the northernmost major city on the North American continent with this categorization. The suburbs to the immediate north and west lie in the transition zone from a humid subtropical (<i>Cfa</i>) to a <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a> (<i>Dfa</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-Peel.2C_M._C..3B_Finlayson.2C_B._L..3B_McMahon.2C_T._A_102-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Peel.2C_M._C..3B_Finlayson.2C_B._L..3B_McMahon.2C_T._A-102">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-newyorkpolonia.com_103-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newyorkpolonia.com-103">[103]</a></sup> The area averages 234 days with at least some sunshine annually, and averages 58% of possible sunshine annually,<sup id="cite_ref-Percent_Sunshine_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Percent_Sunshine-104">[104]</a></sup> accumulating 2,400 to 2,800 hours of sunshine per annum.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>Winters are cold and damp, and prevailing wind patterns that blow offshore minimize the moderating effects of the Atlantic Ocean; yet the Atlantic and the partial shielding of the <a href="/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains" title="Appalachian Mountains">Appalachians</a> keep the city warmer in the winter than inland North American cities at similar or lesser latitudes such as <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cincinnati&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cincinnati (page does not exist)">Cincinnati</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis" title="Indianapolis">Indianapolis</a>. The average daily high temperature in January, the area's coldest month, is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>; however, winter temperatures can occasionally reach as low as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_climate_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_climate-106">[106]</a></sup> and January temperatures have reached the low 70s (Fahrenheit). Spring and autumn are unpredictable and can range from chilly to warm, although they are usually mild with low humidity. Summers are typically warm to hot and humid, with an average daily July high temperature of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. Nighttime conditions are often exacerbated by the <a href="/wiki/Urban_heat_island" title="Urban heat island">urban heat island</a> phenomenon, while daytime temperatures exceed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on average of 17 days each summer and can exceed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Weatherbase_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weatherbase-107">[107]</a></sup> Extreme temperatures have ranged from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, recorded on February 9, 1934, up to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on July 9, 1936.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city receives <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of precipitation annually, which is fairly spread throughout the year.
Average winter snowfall for 1981 to 2010 has been <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, but this usually varies considerably from year to year.<sup id="cite_ref-Weatherbase_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weatherbase-107">[107]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hurricane" title="Hurricane" class="mw-redirect">Hurricanes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tropical_storm" title="Tropical storm" class="mw-redirect">tropical storms</a> are rare in the New York area, but are not unheard of and always have the potential to strike the area.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hurricane_Sandy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hurricane Sandy (page does not exist)">Hurricane Sandy</a> brought a destructive <a href="/wiki/Storm_surge" title="Storm surge">storm surge</a> to New York City on the evening of October 29, 2012, flooding numerous streets, tunnels, and subway lines in Lower Manhattan and other areas of the city and cutting off electricity in many parts of the city and its suburbs.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> The storm and its profound impacts have prompted the discussion of constructing <a href="/wiki/Seawall" title="Seawall">seawalls</a> and other coastal barriers around the shorelines of the city and the metropolitan area to minimize the risk of destructive consequences from another such event in the future.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:New_York_City_weatherbox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:New York City weatherbox (page does not exist)">Template:New York City weatherbox</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="float:right; float:right; margin:1em; margin-top:0; text-align:right; font-size:90%;">

</th></tr>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="left">White (non-Hispanic)</td>
<td>35%</td>

<td>67%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="left">Black</td>
<td>28%</td>
<td>16%</td>
<td>12%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="left">Hispanic (any race)</td>
<td>27%</td>
<td>15%</td>
<td>11%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="left">Asian</td>
<td>10%</td>
<td>6%</td>
<td>4%
</td></tr></table>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Historical_populations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Historical populations (page does not exist)">Template:Historical populations</a>
</p>
<table align="right">
<tr>
<td><div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jueus_ultraortodoxes_satmar_a_brooklyn.jpg" title="File:Jueus ultraortodoxes satmar a brooklyn.jpg">File:Jueus ultraortodoxes satmar a brooklyn.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Brooklyn's growing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jews&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jews (page does not exist)">Jewish</a> community is the largest in the United States, comprising approximately 600,000 individuals.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup></div></div></div>
</td></tr></table>
<p>New York City is the most populous city in the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup>
with an estimated record high of 8,336,697 residents as of 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-census-est-nyc-ny_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-est-nyc-ny-11">[11]</a></sup> incorporating more immigration into the city than outmigration since the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_Census&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 United States Census (page does not exist)">2010 United States Census</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes_a_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes_a-116">[116]</a></sup>
More people live in New York City than in the next two most populous U.S. cities (<a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a>) combined.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[n 1]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mayor <a href="/wiki/Michael_Bloomberg" title="Michael Bloomberg">Michael Bloomberg</a> immediately challenged the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau" title="United States Census Bureau">Census Bureau</a>'s 2010 population count of 8,175,133 as representing an undercount upon release.<sup id="cite_ref-Sam_Roberts_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sam_Roberts-120">[119]</a></sup>
This amounts to about 40% of the state of New York's population and a similar percentage of the metropolitan regional population. In 2006, demographers estimated that New York's population will reach between 9.2 and 9.5&#160;million by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[120]</a></sup>
The city's population in 2010 was 44% <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White American (page does not exist)">white</a> (33.3% non-Hispanic white), 25.5% <a href="/wiki/Black_American" title="Black American" class="mw-redirect">black</a> (23% non-Hispanic black), 0.7% <a href="/w/index.php?title=Native_Americans_in_the_United_State&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Native Americans in the United State (page does not exist)">Native American</a> and 12.7% <a href="/wiki/Asian_American" title="Asian American">Asian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-census-est-nyc-ny_11-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-est-nyc-ny-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans" title="Hispanic and Latino Americans">Hispanics</a> of any race represented 28.6% of the population,<sup id="cite_ref-census-est-nyc-ny_11-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-est-nyc-ny-11">[11]</a></sup> while Asians constituted the fastest-growing segment of the city's population between 2000 and 2010; the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Non-Hispanic_Whites&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Non-Hispanic Whites (page does not exist)">non-Hispanic white</a> population declined 3 percent, the smallest recorded decline in decades; and for the first time since the Civil War, the number of blacks declined over a decade.<sup id="cite_ref-Sam_Roberts_120-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sam_Roberts-120">[119]</a></sup>
In 2010, the city had a population density of 27,532 people per square mile (10,630/km²), rendering it the most densely populated of all municipalities housing over 100,000 residents in the United States; however, several small cities (of less than 100,000) in adjacent <a href="/wiki/Hudson_County,_New_Jersey" title="Hudson County, New Jersey">Hudson County, New Jersey</a> are <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_United_States_cities_by_population_density&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of United States cities by population density (page does not exist)">more dense overall</a>, as per the 2000 Census.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>Geographically co-extensive with <a href="/wiki/New_York_County" title="New York County" class="mw-redirect">New York County</a>, the borough of Manhattan's population density of 66,940 people per square mile<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[122]</a></sup>
(25,846/km²) makes it the highest of any county in the United States<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[123]</a></sup>
and higher than the density of any individual American city.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dragon_in_Chinatown_NYC_Lunar_New_Year.jpg" title="File:Dragon in Chinatown NYC Lunar New Year.jpg">File:Dragon in Chinatown NYC Lunar New Year.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Manhattan" title="Chinatown, Manhattan">Chinatown, Manhattan (紐約華埠)</a>. New York City is home to the largest population of <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Chinese#Current_numbers" title="Overseas Chinese">overseas Chinese</a> outside of <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-queensbuzz_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-queensbuzz-126">[125]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Throughout its history, the city has been a major <a href="/wiki/Port_of_entry" title="Port of entry">port of entry</a> for immigrants into the United States; more than 12 million <a href="/wiki/European_American" title="European American">European</a> immigrants passed through <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Island" title="Ellis Island">Ellis Island</a> between 1892 and 1924.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[126]</a></sup>
The term "<a href="/wiki/Melting_pot" title="Melting pot">melting pot</a>" was first coined to describe densely populated immigrant neighborhoods on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lower_East_Side,_Manhattan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lower East Side, Manhattan (page does not exist)">Lower East Side</a>. By 1900, <a href="/wiki/German_American" title="German American">Germans</a> constituted the largest immigrant group, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Irish_American" title="Irish American">Irish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews" title="Ashkenazi Jews">Jews</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Italian_American" title="Italian American">Italians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[127]</a></sup>
In 1940, whites represented 92% of the city's population.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[128]</a></sup>
</p><p>Approximately 37% of the city's population is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Foreign_born&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Foreign born (page does not exist)">foreign born</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CityDiversity_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CityDiversity-130">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYC_immigration_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_immigration-131">[130]</a></sup>
In New York, no single country or region of origin dominates.<sup id="cite_ref-CityDiversity_130-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CityDiversity-130">[129]</a></sup> The ten largest sources of foreign-born individuals in the city as of 2011 were the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">Dominican Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mexico (page does not exist)">Mexico</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Guyana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guyana (page does not exist)">Guyana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">Jamaica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a>, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trinidad_and_Tobago&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trinidad and Tobago (page does not exist)">Trinidad and Tobago</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[131]</a></sup> while the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bangladeshi_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bangladeshi American (page does not exist)">Bangladeshi</a> immigrant population has since become one of the fastest growing in the city, counting over 74,000 by 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[132]</a></sup> 
The New York region continues to be by far the leading metropolitan gateway for legal immigrants admitted into the United States, substantially exceeding the combined totals of Los Angeles and <a href="/wiki/Miami_metropolitan_area" title="Miami metropolitan area">Miami</a>, the next most popular gateway regions.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[133]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>The New York City metropolitan area is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ethnic_diversity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ethnic diversity (page does not exist)">ethnically diverse</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[137]</a></sup> It is home to the largest <a href="/wiki/American_Jews" title="American Jews">Jewish community</a> outside <a href="/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Israel (page does not exist)">Israel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[138]</a></sup>
The metropolitan area is also home to 20% of the nation's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Americans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian Americans (page does not exist)">Indian Americans</a> and at least 20 <a href="/wiki/Little_India_(location)" title="Little India (location)">Little India</a> enclaves, as well as 15% of all <a href="/wiki/Korean_American" title="Korean American">Korean Americans</a> and four <a href="/wiki/Koreatown,_Manhattan" title="Koreatown, Manhattan">Koreatowns</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-factfinder2.census_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factfinder2.census-140">[139]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[140]</a></sup>
the largest <a href="/wiki/Asian_Indian" title="Asian Indian" class="mw-redirect">Asian Indian</a> population in the Western Hemisphere; the largest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russian_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russian American (page does not exist)">Russian American</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-142">[141]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Italian_American" title="Italian American">Italian American</a>, and <a href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">African American</a> populations; the largest <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South American</a><sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_142-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-142">[141]</a></sup> and second-largest overall <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans" title="Hispanic and Latino Americans">Hispanic</a> communities in the United States; and includes 6 <a href="/wiki/Chinatown" title="Chinatown">Chinatowns</a> in New York City alone<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[142]</a></sup>
with the urban agglomeration comprising as of the 2010 Census a population of 682,265 <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Chinese" title="Overseas Chinese">overseas Chinese</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-factfinder2.census_140-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factfinder2.census-140">[139]</a></sup> the largest outside of <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-queensbuzz_126-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-queensbuzz-126">[125]</a></sup>
Multiple <a href="/wiki/Natural_satellite" title="Natural satellite">satellites</a> of the original <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Manhattan" title="Chinatown, Manhattan">Manhattan Chinatown (紐約華埠)</a>, in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinatown,_Brooklyn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinatown, Brooklyn (page does not exist)">Brooklyn (布鲁克林華埠)</a>, and around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinatown,_Flushing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinatown, Flushing (page does not exist)">Flushing, Queens (法拉盛華埠)</a>, are thriving as traditionally urban enclaves, as large-scale <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_emigration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese emigration (page does not exist)">Chinese immigration</a> continues into New York and neighboring areas.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_142-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-142">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[145]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:New_York_Gay_Pride_2011.jpg" title="File:New York Gay Pride 2011.jpg">File:New York Gay Pride 2011.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">New York City is home to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=LGBT_demographics_of_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="LGBT demographics of the United States (page does not exist)">largest gay and bisexual community</a> in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-GLB_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GLB-147">[146]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New York City alone, according to the 2010 Census, has now become home to more than one million Asian Americans, greater than the combined totals of <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a> and Los Angeles.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[147]</a></sup>
New York contains the highest total Asian population of any U.S. city proper.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[148]</a></sup>
