In 2010, 6.0% of New York City was of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_American" title="Chinese American">Chinese ethnicity</a>, with about forty percent of them living in the borough of <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">Queens</a> alone. <a href="/wiki/Korean_Americans" title="Korean Americans" class="mw-redirect">Koreans</a> made up 1.2% of the city's population, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese American (page does not exist)">Japanese</a> 0.3%. <a href="/wiki/Filipino_American" title="Filipino American">Filipinos</a> were the largest southeast Asian ethnic group at 0.8%, followed by <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_American" title="Vietnamese American">Vietnamese</a>, who made up 0.2% of New York City's population in 2010. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian American (page does not exist)">Indians</a> are the largest <a href="/wiki/South_Asian" title="South Asian" class="mw-redirect">South Asian</a> group, comprising 2.4% of the city's population, with Bangladeshis and <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_American" title="Pakistani American">Pakistanis</a> at 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York City has the largest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Non-Hispanic_whites&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Non-Hispanic whites (page does not exist)">non-Hispanic white</a> population of any American city. At 2.7 million in 2012, New York's non-Hispanic white population is larger than the white populations of Los Angeles (1.1 million), Chicago (865,000), and Houston (550,000) combined.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[150]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/European_American" title="European American">European American</a> population of the city is very diverse. According to 2012 Census estimates, there were roughly 560,000 <a href="/wiki/Italian_American" title="Italian American">Italian Americans</a>, 385,000 <a href="/wiki/Irish_American" title="Irish American">Irish Americans</a>, 253,000 <a href="/wiki/German_American" title="German American">German Americans</a>, 223,000 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russian_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russian American (page does not exist)">Russian Americans</a>, 201,000 <a href="/wiki/Polish_American" title="Polish American">Polish Americans</a>, and 137,000 <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English American (page does not exist)">English Americans</a>. Additionally, <a href="/wiki/Greek_American" title="Greek American">Greek</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_American" title="French American">French Americans</a> numbered 65,000 each, with those of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungarian_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hungarian American (page does not exist)">Hungarian</a> descent clocking in at 60,000 people. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ukrainian_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ukrainian American (page does not exist)">Ukrainian</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish American (page does not exist)">Scottish Americans</a> numbered 55,000 and 35,000, respectively. People of <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_American" title="Norwegian American">Norwegian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Swedish_American" title="Swedish American">Swedish</a> descent both stood at about 20,000 each. Lastly, people of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Czech_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Czech American (page does not exist)">Czech</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuanian_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lithuanian American (page does not exist)">Lithuanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_American" title="Portuguese American">Portuguese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotch-Irish_American" title="Scotch-Irish American">Scotch-Irish</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Welsh_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Welsh American (page does not exist)">Welsh</a> descent all numbered between 12,000-14,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Substantial <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">Dominican</a><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[152]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_people" title="Puerto Rican people">Puerto Rican</a> populations reside in the New York City metropolitan region. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Irish_Americans_in_New_York_City&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irish Americans in New York City (page does not exist)">Irish</a> also have a notable presence; one in 50 New Yorkers of European origin carries a distinctive genetic signature on his <a href="/wiki/Y_chromosome" title="Y chromosome">Y chromosome</a> inherited from the clan of <a href="/wiki/Niall_of_the_Nine_Hostages" title="Niall of the Nine Hostages">Niall of the Nine Hostages</a>, an Irish king of the fifth century A.D.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[153]</a></sup>
or from one of the related clans of Uí Briúin and Uí Fiachrach.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>The New York metropolitan area is home to a self-identifying <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gay (page does not exist)">gay</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bisexuality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bisexuality (page does not exist)">bisexual</a> community estimated at 568,903 individuals, the largest in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-GLB_147-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GLB-147">[146]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_New_York" title="Same-sex marriage in New York">Same-sex marriages in New York</a> were legalized on June 24, 2011 and were authorized to take place beginning 30 days thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York City has a high degree of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Income_disparity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Income disparity (page does not exist)">income disparity</a>. In 2005, the median household income in the wealthiest census tract was $188,697, while in the poorest it was $9,320.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[156]</a></sup>
The disparity is driven by <a href="/wiki/Real_wage" title="Real wage">wage growth</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rate_schedule_(federal_income_tax)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rate schedule (federal income tax) (page does not exist)">high income brackets</a>, while wages have stagnated for middle and lower income brackets. In the first quarter of 2013, the average weekly wage in New York County was $2,448, representing the highest total among the largest counties in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[157]</a></sup>
New York City is home to the highest number of the world's <a href="/wiki/Billionaire" title="Billionaire">billionaires</a>, higher than the next five U.S. cities combined,<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[158]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[160]</a></sup> including former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[161]</a></sup>
Manhattan also experienced a <a href="/wiki/Baby_boom" title="Baby boom">baby boom</a> between 2000 and 2007, during which period the number of children under age 5 living in the borough grew by more than 32%.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[162]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cityscape">Cityscape</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wide_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wide image (page does not exist)">Template:Wide image</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Greenpoint_Houses.JPG" title="File:Greenpoint Houses.JPG">File:Greenpoint Houses.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Landmark 19th-century rowhouses on tree-lined Kent Street in <a href="/wiki/Greenpoint,_Brooklyn" title="Greenpoint, Brooklyn">Greenpoint Historic District</a>, Brooklyn</div></div></div>
<p>New York has architecturally noteworthy buildings in a wide range of styles and from distinct time periods from the <a href="/wiki/Saltbox" title="Saltbox">saltbox style</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wyckoff_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wyckoff House (page does not exist)">Pieter Claesen Wyckoff House</a> in Brooklyn, the oldest section of which dates to 1656, to the modern <a href="/w/index.php?title=One_World_Trade_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="One World Trade Center (page does not exist)">One World Trade Center</a>, the skyscraper currently under construction at <a href="/wiki/Ground_zero#World_Trade_Center" title="Ground zero">Ground Zero</a> in Lower Manhattan and currently the most expensive new office tower in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Skyline" title="Skyline">skyline</a> with its many skyscrapers is universally recognized, and the city has been home to several of the <a href="/wiki/Skyscraper#History_of_the_tallest_skyscrapers" title="Skyscraper">tallest buildings in the world</a>. As of 2011, New York City had 5,937 <a href="/wiki/High-rise" title="High-rise" class="mw-redirect">high-rise</a> buildings, of which 550 completed structures were at least 100 meters high, both second in the world after <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[165]</a></sup> with over 50 completed <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_New_York_City" title="List of tallest buildings in New York City">skyscrapers taller than 656&#160;feet (200 m)</a>. These include the <a href="/wiki/Woolworth_Building" title="Woolworth Building">Woolworth Building</a> (1913), an early <a href="/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture" title="Gothic Revival architecture">gothic revival</a> skyscraper built with massively scaled gothic detailing.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=1916_Zoning_Resolution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1916 Zoning Resolution (page does not exist)">1916 Zoning Resolution</a> required <a href="/w/index.php?title=Setback_(architecture)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Setback (architecture) (page does not exist)">setbacks</a> in new buildings, and restricted towers to a percentage of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Land_lot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Land lot (page does not exist)">lot size</a>, to allow sunlight to reach the streets below.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[166]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> style of the <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Building" title="Chrysler Building">Chrysler Building</a> (1930) and <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a> (1931), with their tapered tops and steel <a href="/wiki/Spire" title="Spire">spires</a>, reflected the zoning requirements. The buildings have distinctive ornamentation, such as the eagles at the corners of the 61st floor on the Chrysler Building, and are considered some of the finest examples of the <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> style.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[167]</a></sup> A highly influential example of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_style_(architecture)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International style (architecture) (page does not exist)">international style</a> in the United States is the <a href="/wiki/Seagram_Building" title="Seagram Building">Seagram Building</a> (1957), distinctive for its façade using visible bronze-toned <a href="/wiki/I-beam" title="I-beam">I-beams</a> to evoke the building's structure. The <a href="/wiki/Cond%C3%A9_Nast_Building" title="Condé Nast Building">Condé Nast Building</a> (2000) is a prominent example of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sustainable_design&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sustainable design (page does not exist)">green design</a> in American skyscrapers.<sup id="cite_ref-greenbuilding_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-greenbuilding-169">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>The character of New York's large residential districts is often defined by the elegant <a href="/wiki/Brownstone" title="Brownstone">brownstone</a> <a href="/wiki/Terraced_house" title="Terraced house">rowhouses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Townhouse" title="Townhouse">townhouses</a>, and shabby <a href="/wiki/Apartment" title="Apartment">tenements</a> that were built during a period of rapid expansion from 1870 to 1930.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[169]</a></sup> In contrast, New York City also has neighborhoods that are less densely populated and feature free-standing dwellings. In neighborhoods such as <a href="/wiki/Riverdale,_Bronx" title="Riverdale, Bronx">Riverdale, Bronx</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ditmas_Park,_Brooklyn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ditmas Park, Brooklyn (page does not exist)">Ditmas Park, Brooklyn</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Douglaston,_Queens" title="Douglaston, Queens">Douglaston, Queens</a>, large single-family homes are common in various architectural styles such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tudor_Revival_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tudor Revival architecture (page does not exist)">Tudor Revival</a> and <a href="/wiki/Victorian_architecture" title="Victorian architecture">Victorian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[170]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stone and brick became the city's building materials of choice after the construction of wood-frame houses was limited in the aftermath of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Fire_of_New_York&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Fire of New York (page does not exist)">Great Fire of 1835</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-lankevich-p82_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lankevich-p82-174">[173]</a></sup> A distinctive feature of many of the city's buildings is the wooden roof-mounted <a href="/wiki/Water_tower" title="Water tower">water towers</a>. In the 1800s, the city required their installation on buildings higher than six stories to prevent the need for excessively high water pressures at lower elevations, which could break municipal water pipes.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[174]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Garden_city_movement" title="Garden city movement">Garden apartments</a> became popular during the 1920s in outlying areas, such as <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Heights,_Queens" title="Jackson Heights, Queens">Jackson Heights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parks">Parks</span></h3>
<p>The City of New York has a complex park system, with various lands operated by the <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">National Park Service</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_York_State_Office_of_Parks,_Recreation_and_Historic_Preservation" title="New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation">New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation" title="New York City Department of Parks and Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</a>.
</p><p>In its 2013 ParkScore ranking, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trust_for_Public_Land&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trust for Public Land (page does not exist)">The Trust for Public Land</a> reported that New York City had the 2<sup>nd</sup> best park system among the 50 most populous U.S. cities.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[176]</a></sup> ParkScore ranks urban park systems by a formula that analyzes median park size, park acres as percent of city area, the percent of city residents within a half-mile of a park, spending of park services per resident, and the number of playgrounds per 10,000 residents.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="National_Park_System_units_within_city_limits">National Park System units within city limits</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Manhattan_from_helicopter_edit1.jpg" title="File:Manhattan from helicopter edit1.jpg">File:Manhattan from helicopter edit1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Statue_of_Liberty_National_Monument&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Statue of Liberty National Monument (page does not exist)">Statue of Liberty National Monument</a>, in May 2001, with the former Twin Towers of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Trade_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Trade Center (page does not exist)">World Trade Center</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a> in the background.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Gateway_National_Recreation_Area" title="Gateway National Recreation Area">Gateway National Recreation Area</a> contains over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in total, most of it surrounded by New York City;<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[177]</a></sup> the New York State portion includes the <a href="/wiki/Jamaica_Bay_Wildlife_Refuge" title="Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge">Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge</a> in Brooklyn and Queens, over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of <a href="/wiki/Salt_marsh" title="Salt marsh">salt marsh</a>, islands and water that includes most of <a href="/wiki/Jamaica_Bay" title="Jamaica Bay">Jamaica Bay</a>. Also in Queens the park includes a significant portion of the western <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rockaway_Peninsula&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rockaway Peninsula (page does not exist)">Rockaway Peninsula</a>, most notably <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jacob_Riis_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jacob Riis Park (page does not exist)">Jacob Riis Park</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Tilden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Tilden (page does not exist)">Fort Tilden</a>. In Staten Island, the park includes <a href="/wiki/Fort_Wadsworth" title="Fort Wadsworth">Fort Wadsworth</a>, with historic pre-Civil War era <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battery_Weed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battery Weed (page does not exist)">Battery Weed</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Tompkins_Quadrangle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Tompkins Quadrangle (page does not exist)">Fort Tompkins</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Kills_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Kills Park (page does not exist)">Great Kills Park</a>, with beaches, trails, and a marina.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Statue_of_Liberty_National_Monument&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Statue of Liberty National Monument (page does not exist)">Statue of Liberty National Monument and Ellis Island Immigration Museum</a> are managed by the National Park Service and are in both the states of New York and <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>. They are joined in the harbor by <a href="/wiki/Governors_Island_National_Monument" title="Governors Island National Monument">Governors Island National Monument</a>, in New York. Historic sites under federal management on Manhattan Island include <a href="/wiki/Castle_Clinton_National_Monument" title="Castle Clinton National Monument" class="mw-redirect">Castle Clinton National Monument</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Federal_Hall_National_Memorial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Federal Hall National Memorial (page does not exist)">Federal Hall National Memorial</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theodore_Roosevelt_Birthplace_National_Historic_Site&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site (page does not exist)">Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_Grant_National_Memorial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="General Grant National Memorial (page does not exist)">General Grant National Memorial</a> ("Grant's Tomb"); <a href="/wiki/African_Burial_Ground_National_Monument" title="African Burial Ground National Monument">African Burial Ground National Monument</a>; and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hamilton_Grange_National_Memorial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hamilton Grange National Memorial (page does not exist)">Hamilton Grange National Memorial</a>.  Hundreds of private properties are listed on the <a href="/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places" title="National Register of Historic Places">National Register of Historic Places</a> or as a <a href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark" title="National Historic Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a> such as, for example, the <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_Inn" title="Stonewall Inn">Stonewall Inn</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a> as the catalyst of the modern <a href="/wiki/Gay_rights_movement" title="Gay rights movement" class="mw-redirect">gay rights movement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[178]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[179]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="New_York_State_Parks">New York State Parks</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
There are seven state parks within the confines of New York City, including <a href="/wiki/Clay_Pit_Ponds_State_Park_Preserve" title="Clay Pit Ponds State Park Preserve">Clay Pit Ponds State Park Preserve</a>, a natural area which includes extensive riding trails, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Riverbank_State_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Riverbank State Park (page does not exist)">Riverbank State Park</a>, a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> facility that rises <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> over the Hudson River.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[180]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="New_York_City_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bronx_Zoo_reindeer.jpg" title="File:Bronx Zoo reindeer.jpg">File:Bronx Zoo reindeer.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Reindeer" title="Reindeer">Reindeer</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>, the world's largest metropolitan zoo.<sup id="cite_ref-BronxZoo_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BronxZoo-182">[181]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New York City has over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of municipal parkland and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of public beaches.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[182]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Park" title="Park">Parks</a> in New York City include <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prospect_Park_(Brooklyn)" title="Prospect Park (Brooklyn)">Prospect Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows%E2%80%93Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows–Corona Park">Flushing Meadows–Corona Park</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Forest_Park_(Queens,_New_York)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forest Park (Queens, New York) (page does not exist)">Forest Park</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Park" title="Washington Square Park">Washington Square Park</a>. The largest municipal park in the city is <a href="/wiki/Pelham_Bay_Park" title="Pelham Bay Park">Pelham Bay Park</a> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[183]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a> an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> park in Manhattan, is the most visited city park in the United States, with 25 million visitors each year.<sup id="cite_ref-TPL.org-CFCPE_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TPL.org-CFCPE-185">[184]</a></sup>  The park contains a myriad of attractions; there are several lakes and ponds, two ice-skating rinks, the <a href="/wiki/Central_Park_Zoo" title="Central Park Zoo">Central Park Zoo</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Park_Conservatory_Garden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Park Conservatory Garden (page does not exist)">Central Park Conservatory Garden</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> Jackie Onassis Reservoir. Indoor attractions include <a href="/wiki/Belvedere_Castle" title="Belvedere Castle">Belvedere Castle</a> with its nature center, the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater, and the historic Carousel. On October 23, 2012, <a href="/wiki/Hedge_fund" title="Hedge fund">hedge fund</a> manager <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Paulson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Paulson (page does not exist)">John A. Paulson</a> announced a $100 million gift to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Park_Conservancy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Park Conservancy (page does not exist)">Central Park Conservancy</a>, the largest ever monetary donation to New York City's park system.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[185]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Prospect_Park_(Brooklyn)" title="Prospect Park (Brooklyn)">Prospect Park</a> in Brooklyn has a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> meadow, a lake and extensive woodlands. Within the park is the historic Battle Pass, prominent in the Battle of Long Island.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[186]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows%E2%80%93Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows–Corona Park">Flushing Meadows–Corona Park</a> in Queens, the city's third largest park, was the setting for the <a href="/wiki/1939_New_York_World%27s_Fair" title="1939 New York World's Fair">1939 World's Fair</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1964_New_York_World%27s_Fair" title="1964 New York World's Fair">1964 World's Fair</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[187]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> Over a fifth of the Bronx's area, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, is given over to open space and parks, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Van_Cortlandt_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Van Cortlandt Park (page does not exist)">Van Cortlandt Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pelham_Bay_Park" title="Pelham Bay Park">Pelham Bay Park</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_Botanical_Gardens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York Botanical Gardens (page does not exist)">New York Botanical Gardens</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[188]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> In Staten Island, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Conference_House_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Conference House Park (page does not exist)">Conference House Park</a> contains the historic <a href="/wiki/Conference_House" title="Conference House">Conference House</a>, site of the only attempt of a peaceful resolution to the American Revolution, attended by <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a> representing the Americans and <a href="/wiki/Richard_Howe,_1st_Earl_Howe" title="Richard Howe, 1st Earl Howe">Lord Howe</a> representing the <a href="/wiki/British_Crown" title="British Crown" class="mw-redirect">British Crown</a>. The historic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Burial_Ridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Burial Ridge (page does not exist)">Burial Ridge</a>, the largest Native American burial ground within New York City, is within the park.
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wide_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wide image (page does not exist)">Template:Wide image</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Boroughs">Boroughs</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<table align="right">

<tr>
<td><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map_Julius_Schorzman.png" title="File:5 Boroughs Labels New York City Map Julius Schorzman.png">File:5 Boroughs Labels New York City Map Julius Schorzman.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Five Boroughs of New York City: <b><a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan"><span style="color:navy;">1:&#160;Manhattan</span></b></a> <b><a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn"><span style="color:#da0;">2:&#160;Brooklyn </span></b></a> <b><a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens"><span style="color:coral;">3:&#160;Queens</span></b></a> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bronx&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bronx (page does not exist)"><span style="color:red;">4:&#160;The Bronx</span></b></a> <b><a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island"><span style="color:purple;">5:&#160;Staten Island</span></b></a></div></div></div>
</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:NYC_boroughs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:NYC boroughs (page does not exist)">Template:NYC boroughs</a>
</td></tr></table>
<p>New York City is composed of five <a href="/w/index.php?title=Borough_(New_York_City)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Borough (New York City) (page does not exist)">boroughs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[189]</a></sup> Each borough is coextensive with a respective <a href="/wiki/County_(United_States)" title="County (United States)">county</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York (page does not exist)">New York State</a> as shown below.
</p><p>Throughout the boroughs there are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Neighborhoods_in_New_York_City&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Neighborhoods in New York City (page does not exist)">hundreds of distinct neighborhoods</a>, many with a definable history and character to call their own. If the boroughs were each independent cities, four of the boroughs (Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan, and The Bronx) would be among the ten most populous cities in the United States.
</p>
<ul>
<li> <b><a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a></b> (New York County) is the most densely populated borough and is home to <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a> and most of the city's skyscrapers. Most of the borough is on Manhattan Island, at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>.  Manhattan is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Financial_center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Financial center (page does not exist)">financial center</a> of the city and contains the headquarters of many major corporations, the UN, a number of important universities, and many cultural attractions. Manhattan is loosely divided into <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower</a>, <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Upper_Manhattan" title="Upper Manhattan">Uptown</a> regions. Uptown Manhattan is divided by Central Park into the <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Side" title="Upper East Side">Upper East Side</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Upper_West_Side" title="Upper West Side">Upper West Side</a>, and above the park is <a href="/wiki/Harlem" title="Harlem">Harlem</a>. New York City's remaining four boroughs are collectively referred to as the "outer boroughs".
</li>
<li> <b><a href="/wiki/The_Bronx" title="The Bronx">The Bronx</a></b> (Bronx County) is New York City's northernmost borough, the location of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yankee_Stadium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yankee Stadium (page does not exist)">Yankee Stadium</a>, home of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_Yankees&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York Yankees (page does not exist)">New York Yankees</a>, and home to the largest <a href="/wiki/Housing_cooperative" title="Housing cooperative">cooperatively owned housing</a> complex in the United States, <a href="/wiki/Co-op_City,_Bronx" title="Co-op City, Bronx">Co-op City</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[190]</a></sup> Except for a small section of Manhattan known as <a href="/wiki/Marble_Hill,_Manhattan" title="Marble Hill, Manhattan">Marble Hill</a>, the Bronx is the only section of the city that is part of the United States' <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mainland_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mainland United States (page does not exist)">mainland</a>. It is home to the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>, the world's largest metropolitan zoo,<sup id="cite_ref-BronxZoo_182-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BronxZoo-182">[181]</a></sup> which spans <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and is home to over 6,000 animals.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[191]</a></sup> The Bronx is the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Rapping" title="Rapping">rap</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_culture" title="Hip hop culture" class="mw-redirect">hip hop culture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Toop-RapAttack2_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toop-RapAttack2-193">[192]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <b><a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a></b> (Kings County) on the western tip of <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>, is the city's most populous borough and was an independent city until 1898. Brooklyn is known for its cultural, social and ethnic diversity, an independent art scene, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Brooklyn_neighborhoods" title="List of Brooklyn neighborhoods">distinct neighborhoods</a> and a distinctive architectural heritage. <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Brooklyn" title="Downtown Brooklyn">Downtown Brooklyn</a> is the only central core neighborhood in the outer boroughs. The borough has a long beachfront shoreline including <a href="/wiki/Coney_Island" title="Coney Island">Coney Island</a>, established in the 1870s as one of the earliest amusement grounds in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[193]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <b><a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">Queens</a></b> (Queens County) on Long Island east of Brooklyn, is geographically the largest borough and the most ethnically diverse county in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-queensdiverse_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-queensdiverse-195">[194]</a></sup> Historically a collection of small towns and villages founded by the Dutch, the borough has since developed both commercial and residential prominence. Queens County is the only large county in the United States where the median income among African Americans, approximately $52,000 a year, is higher than that of <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White American (page does not exist)">White Americans</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[195]</a></sup> Queens is the site of <a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">Citi Field</a>, the home of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">New York Mets</a>, and annually hosts the <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">U.S. Open tennis tournament</a>. Additionally, it is home to two of the three major airports serving the <a href="/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area" title="New York metropolitan area">New York metropolitan area</a>, <a href="/wiki/LaGuardia_Airport" title="LaGuardia Airport">LaGuardia Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy International Airport</a>. (The third is <a href="/wiki/Newark_Liberty_International_Airport" title="Newark Liberty International Airport">Newark Liberty International Airport</a> in <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark</a>, New Jersey.)
</li>
<li> <b><a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a></b> (Richmond County) is the most suburban in character of the five boroughs. Staten Island is connected to Brooklyn by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Verrazano-Narrows Bridge (page does not exist)">Verrazano-Narrows Bridge</a> and to Manhattan by way of the free <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry" title="Staten Island Ferry">Staten Island Ferry</a>. The Staten Island Ferry is one of the most popular tourist attractions in New York City as it provides unsurpassed views of the <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Island" title="Ellis Island">Ellis Island</a>, and lower Manhattan. In central Staten Island, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Greenbelt" title="Staten Island Greenbelt">Staten Island Greenbelt</a> has some <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of walking trails and one of the last undisturbed forests in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[196]</a></sup> Designated in 1984 to protect the island's natural lands, the Greenbelt comprises seven city parks.
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture_and_contemporary_life">Culture and contemporary life</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Metropolitan_museum_of_art_2.jpg" title="File:Metropolitan museum of art 2.jpg">File:Metropolitan museum of art 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/The_Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="The Metropolitan Museum of Art" class="mw-redirect">The Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>, part of <a href="/wiki/Museum_Mile,_New_York_City" title="Museum Mile, New York City" class="mw-redirect">Museum Mile</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hill" title="Carnegie Hill">Carnegie Hill</a> neighborhood of Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Side" title="Upper East Side">Upper East Side</a>, is one of the largest museums in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[197]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New York City has been described as the cultural capital of the world by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Consul_(representative)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Consul (representative) (page does not exist)">diplomatic consulates</a> of <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a><sup id="cite_ref-culture1_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-culture1-5">[5]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a><sup id="cite_ref-culture2_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-culture2-199">[198]</a></sup> and by New York's <a href="/wiki/Baruch_College" title="Baruch College">Baruch College</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-culture3_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-culture3-200">[199]</a></sup> A book containing a series of essays titled <i>New York, culture capital of the world, 1940–1965</i> has also been published as showcased by the <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Australia" title="National Library of Australia">National Library of Australia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-culture1_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-culture1-5">[5]</a></sup> In describing New York, author <a href="/wiki/Tom_Wolfe" title="Tom Wolfe">Tom Wolfe</a> said, "Culture just seems to be in the air, like part of the weather."<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>Numerous major American cultural movements began in the city, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Harlem_Renaissance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Harlem Renaissance (page does not exist)">Harlem Renaissance</a>, which established the African-American literary canon in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[201]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[202]</a></sup>  The city was a center of <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a><sup id="cite_ref-Jazzzz_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jazzzz-204">[203]</a></sup>  in the 1940s, <a href="/wiki/Abstract_expressionism" title="Abstract expressionism">abstract expressionism</a> in the 1950s and the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_culture" title="Hip hop culture" class="mw-redirect">hip hop</a> in the 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-BPOHPINY_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BPOHPINY-205">[204]</a></sup>  The city's <a href="/wiki/Punk_subculture" title="Punk subculture">punk</a><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[205]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hardcore_punk" title="Hardcore punk">hardcore</a><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[206]</a></sup>  scenes were influential in the 1970s and 1980s, and the city has long had a flourishing scene for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jewish_American_literature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jewish American literature (page does not exist)">Jewish American literature</a>.
</p><p>The city is the birthplace of many cultural movements, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Harlem_Renaissance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Harlem Renaissance (page does not exist)">Harlem Renaissance</a> in literature and visual art; <a href="/wiki/Abstract_expressionism" title="Abstract expressionism">abstract expressionism</a> (also known as the <a href="/wiki/New_York_School" title="New York School">New York School</a>) in painting; and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hip_hop_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hip hop music (page does not exist)">hip hop</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Toop-RapAttack2_193-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toop-RapAttack2-193">[192]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Punk_rock" title="Punk rock">punk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salsa_music" title="Salsa music">salsa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Disco" title="Disco">disco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_music" title="Freestyle music">freestyle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tin_Pan_Alley" title="Tin Pan Alley">Tin Pan Alley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">Jazz</a> in music. New York City has been considered the dance capital of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[207]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[209]</a></sup> The city is also widely celebrated in popular lore, frequently the setting for books, movies (see <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_in_film&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York in film (page does not exist)">New York in film</a>), television programs, etc.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Entertainment_and_performing_arts">Entertainment and performing arts</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg" title="File:Lincoln Center Twilight.jpg">File:Lincoln Center Twilight.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts" title="Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts">Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts</a> is home of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Philharmonic" title="New York Philharmonic">New York Philharmonic</a> and other performing arts.</div></div></div>
<p>New York is a prominent location in the American entertainment industry, with films, television series, books, and other media being set there. As of 2008, New York City is the second largest center for the film industry in the United States, with 63,000 workers who were paid as much as $5 billion in wages in 2008,<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[210]</a></sup> and by volume, New York is the world leader in <a href="/wiki/Independent_film" title="Independent film">independent film</a> production.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[211]</a></sup> The Association of Independent Commercial Producers is also based in New York City.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[212]</a></sup> The city has more than 2,000 arts and cultural organizations and more than 500 art galleries of all sizes.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_arts_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_arts-214">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city government funds the arts with a larger annual budget than the <a href="/wiki/National_Endowment_for_the_Arts" title="National Endowment for the Arts">National Endowment for the Arts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_arts_214-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_arts-214">[213]</a></sup> Wealthy industrialists in the 19th century built a network of major cultural institutions, such as the famed <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hall" title="Carnegie Hall">Carnegie Hall</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="The Metropolitan Museum of Art" class="mw-redirect">The Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>, that would become internationally established. The advent of electric lighting led to elaborate theater productions, and in the 1880s New York City theaters on <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(New_York_City)" title="Broadway (New York City)">Broadway</a> and along 42nd Street began featuring a new stage form that became known as the <a href="/wiki/Musical_theatre" title="Musical theatre">Broadway musical</a>. Strongly influenced by the city's immigrants, productions such as those of <a href="/wiki/Edward_Harrigan" title="Edward Harrigan">Harrigan and Hart</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_M._Cohan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George M. Cohan (page does not exist)">George M. Cohan</a>, and others used song in narratives that often reflected themes of hope and ambition.
</p><p>Forty of the city's theaters, with more than 500 seats each, are collectively known as "<a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">Broadway</a>," after the <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(New_York_City)" title="Broadway (New York City)">major thoroughfare</a> that crosses the <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theater_District&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theater District (page does not exist)">Theater District</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[214]</a></sup>  sometimes referred to as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Great_White_Way&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Great White Way (page does not exist)">The Great White Way</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[215]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[217]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts" title="Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts">Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts</a> is home to 12 influential arts organizations, including the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Opera" title="Metropolitan Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Opera" title="New York City Opera">New York City Opera</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_Philharmonic" title="New York Philharmonic">New York Philharmonic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Ballet" title="New York City Ballet">New York City Ballet</a>, as well as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vivian_Beaumont_Theater&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vivian Beaumont Theater (page does not exist)">Vivian Beaumont Theater</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Juilliard_School" title="Juilliard School">Juilliard School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jazz_at_Lincoln_Center" title="Jazz at Lincoln Center">Jazz at Lincoln Center</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alice_Tully_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alice Tully Hall (page does not exist)">Alice Tully Hall</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lee_Strasberg_Theatre_and_Film_Institute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute (page does not exist)">Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute</a> is in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Union_Square_(New_York_City)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Union Square (New York City) (page does not exist)">Union Square</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tisch_School_of_the_Arts" title="Tisch School of the Arts">Tisch School of the Arts</a> is based at New York University, while <a href="/wiki/Central_Park_SummerStage" title="Central Park SummerStage">Central Park SummerStage</a> presents performances of free plays and music in Central Park.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[218]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:New_york_times_square-terabass.jpg" title="File:New york times square-terabass.jpg">File:New york times square-terabass.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a> has the highest annual attendance rate of any tourist attraction in the US,<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[219]</a></sup> and according to <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Travel_%2B_Leisure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Travel + Leisure (page does not exist)">Travel + Leisure</a></i> magazine's October 2011 survey, the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Joshua_Pramis_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Joshua_Pramis-31">[31]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Tourism is one of New York City's most vital industries, with more than 40 million combined domestic and international tourists visiting each year in the past five years.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_Statistics_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_Statistics-221">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>Major destinations include the <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a>; <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a>; <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Island" title="Ellis Island">Ellis Island</a>; Broadway theater productions; museums such as the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="Metropolitan Museum of Art">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>; greenspaces such as Central Park and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_Square_Park,_New_York&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington Square Park, New York (page does not exist)">Washington Square Park</a>; <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center" title="Rockefeller Center">Rockefeller Center</a>; Times Square; the Manhattan Chinatown; luxury shopping along <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">Fifth</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madison_Avenue" title="Madison Avenue">Madison Avenues</a>; and events such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York%27s_Village_Halloween_Parade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York's Village Halloween Parade (page does not exist)">Halloween Parade</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Macy%27s_Thanksgiving_Day_Parade" title="Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade">Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade</a>; the lighting of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rockefeller_Center_Christmas_Tree&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree (page does not exist)">Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree</a>; the <a href="/wiki/St._Patrick%27s_Day#New_York_City" title="St. Patrick's Day" class="mw-redirect">St. Patrick's Day parade</a>; seasonal activities such as ice skating in Central Park in the wintertime; the <a href="/wiki/Tribeca_Film_Festival" title="Tribeca Film Festival">Tribeca Film Festival</a>; and free performances in Central Park at Summerstage. Special experiences outside the key tourist areas of the city include the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>; <a href="/wiki/Coney_Island" title="Coney Island">Coney Island</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flushing_Meadows-Corona_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flushing Meadows-Corona Park (page does not exist)">Flushing Meadows-Corona Park</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Botanical_Garden" title="New York Botanical Garden">New York Botanical Garden</a>. Plans were unveiled by Mayor Michael Bloomberg on September 27, 2012 for the New York Wheel, the world's tallest <a href="/wiki/Ferris_wheel" title="Ferris wheel">ferris wheel</a>, to be built at the northern shore of Staten Island, overlooking the Statue of Liberty, New York Harbor, and the Lower Manhattan skyline.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010, New York City received nearly 49 million tourists,<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[224]</a></sup> subsequently surpassed by a record 50 million tourists in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[225]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[226]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rockefeller_Center_(2006).JPG" title="File:Rockefeller Center (2006).JPG">File:Rockefeller Center (2006).JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center" title="Rockefeller Center">Rockefeller Center</a> is home to <a href="/w/index.php?title=NBC_Studios_(New_York)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NBC Studios (New York) (page does not exist)">NBC Studios</a></div></div></div>
<p>New York City is a center for the television, <a href="/wiki/Film_industry" title="Film industry">film</a>, advertising, music, newspaper, and book publishing industries and is also the largest media market in North America (followed by Los Angeles, Chicago, and <a href="/wiki/Toronto" title="Toronto">Toronto</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[227]</a></sup> Some of the city's <a href="/wiki/Media_conglomerate" title="Media conglomerate">media conglomerates</a> include <a href="/wiki/Time_Warner" title="Time Warner">Time Warner</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomson_Reuters_Corporation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomson Reuters Corporation (page does not exist)">Thomson Reuters Corporation</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Associated_Press&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Associated Press (page does not exist)">Associated Press</a>, the <a href="/wiki/News_Corporation" title="News Corporation">News Corporation</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Company" title="The New York Times Company">The New York Times Company</a>, <a href="/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">NBCUniversal</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Hearst_Corporation" title="Hearst Corporation">Hearst Corporation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Viacom" title="Viacom">Viacom</a>. Seven of the world's top eight global <a href="/wiki/Advertising_agency" title="Advertising agency">advertising agency</a> networks have their headquarters in New York.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[228]</a></sup> Two of the "<a href="/wiki/Music_industry" title="Music industry">Big three</a>" record labels' headquarters are in New York: <a href="/wiki/Sony_Music_Entertainment" title="Sony Music Entertainment">Sony Music Entertainment</a> and <a href="/wiki/Warner_Music_Group" title="Warner Music Group">Warner Music Group</a>. <a href="/wiki/Universal_Music_Group" title="Universal Music Group">Universal Music Group</a> also has offices in New York.
One-third of all American <a href="/wiki/Independent_film" title="Independent film">independent films</a> are produced in New York.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_Media_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_Media-230">[229]</a></sup>
</p><p>More than 200 newspapers and 350 consumer magazines have an office in the city<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_Media_230-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_Media-230">[229]</a></sup> and the book-publishing industry employs about 25,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup> Two of the three national daily newspapers in the United States are New York papers: <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>, which has won the most <a href="/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize" title="Pulitzer Prize">Pulitzer Prizes</a> for journalism. Major tabloid newspapers in the city include: <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_News_(New_York)" title="Daily News (New York)">The New York Daily News</a></i>, which was founded in 1919 by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Medill_Patterson" title="Joseph Medill Patterson">Joseph Medill Patterson</a><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[231]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Post" title="New York Post">The New York Post</a></i>, founded in 1801 by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[232]</a></sup> The city also has a comprehensive ethnic press, with 270 newspapers and magazines published in more than 40 languages.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[233]</a></sup> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=El_Diario_La_Prensa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="El Diario La Prensa (page does not exist)">El Diario La Prensa</a></i> is New York's largest <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish-language</a> daily and the oldest in the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[234]</a></sup>
<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_Amsterdam_News&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York Amsterdam News (page does not exist)">The New York Amsterdam News</a></i>, published in Harlem, is a prominent African American newspaper.
<i><a href="/wiki/The_Village_Voice" title="The Village Voice">The Village Voice</a></i> is the largest <a href="/wiki/Alternative_newspaper" title="Alternative newspaper">alternative newspaper</a>.
</p><p>The television industry developed in New York and is a significant employer in the city's economy. The four major American <a href="/wiki/Broadcast_network" title="Broadcast network">broadcast networks</a> are all headquartered in New York: <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a>, <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a>, and <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a>.
Many cable channels are based in the city as well, including <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fox_News_Channel" title="Fox News Channel">Fox News</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=HBO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="HBO (page does not exist)">HBO</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Comedy_Central" title="Comedy Central">Comedy Central</a>. In 2005, there were more than 100 television shows taped in New York City.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[235]</a></sup> The City of New York operates a public broadcast service, <a href="/w/index.php?title=NYCTV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NYCTV (page does not exist)">NYCTV</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[236]</a></sup> that has produced several original Emmy Award-winning shows covering music and culture in city neighborhoods and city government.
</p><p>New York is also a major center for <a href="/wiki/Non-commercial_educational" title="Non-commercial educational">non-commercial educational</a> media. The oldest <a href="/wiki/Public-access_television" title="Public-access television">public-access television</a> channel in the United States is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Manhattan_Neighborhood_Network&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Manhattan Neighborhood Network (page does not exist)">Manhattan Neighborhood Network</a>, founded in 1971.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[237]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/WNET" title="WNET">WNET</a> is the city's major public television station and a primary source of national <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_Broadcasting_Service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public Broadcasting Service (page does not exist)">Public Broadcasting Service</a> (PBS) television programming. <a href="/wiki/WNYC" title="WNYC">WNYC</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Public_radio" title="Public radio" class="mw-redirect">public radio</a> station owned by the city until 1997, has the largest public radio audience in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[238]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg" title="File:Smorgasburg in Dumbo.jpg">File:Smorgasburg in Dumbo.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Smorgasburg opened in 2011 as an open air food market, and is part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brooklyn_Flea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brooklyn Flea (page does not exist)">Brooklyn Flea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New York City's food culture includes a variety of international cuisines influenced by the city's immigrant history. <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central European</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Italian_diaspora&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Italian diaspora (page does not exist)">Italian</a> immigrants have made the city famous for <a href="/wiki/Bagel" title="Bagel">bagels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cheesecake#North_America" title="Cheesecake">cheesecake</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_York-style_pizza" title="New York-style pizza">New York-style pizza</a>, while <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_restaurant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese restaurant (page does not exist)">Chinese</a> and other Asian restaurants, burger joints, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trattoria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trattoria (page does not exist)">trattorias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diner" title="Diner">diners</a>, and coffee shops are ubiquitous. Some 4,000 mobile food vendors licensed by the city, many immigrant-owned, have made <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle Eastern</a> foods such as <a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">kebabs</a><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup> popular examples of modern New York <a href="/wiki/Street_food" title="Street food">street food</a>. The city is also home to many of the finest and most diverse <a href="/wiki/Haute_cuisine" title="Haute cuisine">haute cuisine</a> restaurants in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[241]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Health_and_Mental_Hygiene" title="New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene">New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene</a> assigns letter grades to the city's 24,000 restaurants based upon their inspection results.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Accent">Accent</span></h3>
<p>The New York area has a distinctive regional speech pattern called the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_dialect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York dialect (page does not exist)">New York dialect</a>, alternatively known as <i>Brooklynese</i> or <i>New Yorkese</i>. It is generally considered one of the most recognizable accents within <a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">American English</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup> The classic version of this dialect is centered on middle and working-class people of <a href="/wiki/European_American" title="European American">European</a> descent, and the influx of non-European immigrants in recent decades has led to changes in this distinctive dialect.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-245">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p>The traditional New York area accent is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rhotic_and_non-rhotic_accents&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rhotic and non-rhotic accents (page does not exist)">non-rhotic</a>, so that the sound <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɹ]</span> does not appear at the end of a syllable or immediately before a consonant; hence the pronunciation of the city name as "New Yawk."<sup id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_245-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-245">[244]</a></sup> There is no <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɹ]</span> in words like <i>park</i> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[pɑək]</span> or <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[pɒək]</span> (with vowel backed and <a href="/wiki/Vowel_breaking" title="Vowel breaking">diphthongized</a> due to the low-back chain shift), <i>butter</i> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[bʌɾə]</span>, or <i>here</i> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[hiə]</span>. In another feature called the low back chain shift, the <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɔ]</span> vowel sound of words like <i>talk</i>, <i>law</i>, <i>cross</i>, <i>chocolate</i>, and <i>coffee</i> and the often <a href="/wiki/Homophonous" title="Homophonous" class="mw-redirect">homophonous</a> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɔr]</span> in <i>core</i> and <i>more</i> are tensed and usually raised more than in <a href="/wiki/General_American" title="General American">General American</a>.
</p><p>In the most old-fashioned and extreme versions of the New York dialect, the vowel sounds of words like "girl" and of words like "oil" become a diphthong <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɜɪ]</span>. This is often misperceived by speakers of other accents as a reversal of the <i>er</i> and <i>oy</i> sounds, so that <i>girl</i> is pronounced "goil" and <i>oil</i> is pronounced "erl"; this leads to the caricature of New Yorkers saying things like "Joizey" (Jersey), "Toidy-Toid Street" (33rd St.) and "terlet" (toilet).<sup id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_245-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-245">[244]</a></sup> The character <a href="/wiki/Archie_Bunker" title="Archie Bunker">Archie Bunker</a> from the 1970s sitcom <i><a href="/wiki/All_in_the_Family" title="All in the Family">All in the Family</a></i> (played by <a href="/wiki/Carroll_O%27Connor" title="Carroll O'Connor">Carroll O'Connor</a>) was a good example of such a speaker. This speech pattern is no longer prevalent.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_245-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-245">[244]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p><p>New York City is home to the <a href="/wiki/Headquarters" title="Headquarters">headquarters</a> of the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">National Football League</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[245]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[246]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[247]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">National Hockey League</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[248]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Soccer" title="Major League Soccer">Major League Soccer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[249]</a></sup> Four of the ten most expensive <a href="/wiki/Stadium" title="Stadium">stadiums</a> ever built worldwide (<a href="/w/index.php?title=MetLife_Stadium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MetLife Stadium (page does not exist)">MetLife Stadium</a>, the new <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yankee_Stadium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yankee Stadium (page does not exist)">Yankee Stadium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">Citi Field</a>) are in the New York metropolitan area.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[250]</a></sup> The New York metropolitan area has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_American_and_Canadian_cities_by_number_of_major_professional_sports_franchises" title="List of American and Canadian cities by number of major professional sports franchises">most</a> professional sports teams in these five leagues.
</p><p>New York has been described as the "Capital of Baseball".<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[251]</a></sup>  There have been 35 Major League Baseball <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Series (page does not exist)">World Series</a> and 73 pennants won by New York teams.  It is one of only five metro areas (<a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_metropolitan_area" title="Los Angeles metropolitan area">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicago_metropolitan_area" title="Chicago metropolitan area">Chicago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baltimore%E2%80%93Washington_metropolitan_area" title="Baltimore–Washington metropolitan area">Baltimore–Washington</a>, and the San Francisco Bay Area being the others) to have two baseball teams. Additionally, there have been 14 World Series in which two New York City teams played each other, known as a <a href="/wiki/Subway_Series" title="Subway Series">Subway Series</a> and occurring most recently in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wsy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wsy (page does not exist)">Template:Wsy</a>. No other metropolitan area has had this happen more than once (Chicago in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wsy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wsy (page does not exist)">Template:Wsy</a>, St. Louis in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wsy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wsy (page does not exist)">Template:Wsy</a>, and the San Francisco Bay Area in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wsy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wsy (page does not exist)">Template:Wsy</a>).
</p><p>The city's two current Major League Baseball teams are the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">New York Mets</a><sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[252]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_Yankees&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York Yankees (page does not exist)">New York Yankees</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[253]</a></sup> who compete in six games of <a href="/wiki/Interleague_play" title="Interleague play">interleague play</a> every regular season that has also come to be called the <a href="/wiki/Subway_Series" title="Subway Series">Subway Series</a>.  The Yankees have won a record 27 championships,<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[254]</a></sup>  while the Mets have won the World Series twice.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[255]</a></sup>  The city also was once home to the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Dodgers" title="Brooklyn Dodgers" class="mw-redirect">Brooklyn Dodgers</a> (now the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Dodgers" title="Los Angeles Dodgers">Los Angeles Dodgers</a>), who won the World Series once,<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[256]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_Giants_(NL)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York Giants (NL) (page does not exist)">New York Giants</a> (now the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Giants" title="San Francisco Giants">San Francisco Giants</a>), who won the World Series five times. Both teams moved to California in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[257]</a></sup>  There are also two <a href="/wiki/Minor_League_Baseball" title="Minor League Baseball">Minor League Baseball</a> teams in the city, the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Cyclones" title="Brooklyn Cyclones">Brooklyn Cyclones</a><sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[258]</a></sup>  and <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Yankees" title="Staten Island Yankees">Staten Island Yankees</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[259]</a></sup>
