</p><p>The city is represented in the National Football League by the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Giants" title="New York Giants">New York Giants</a> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Jets" title="New York Jets">New York Jets</a>, although both teams play their home games at MetLife Stadium in nearby <a href="/wiki/East_Rutherford,_New_Jersey" title="East Rutherford, New Jersey">East Rutherford, New Jersey</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[260]</a></sup> which will host <a href="/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XLVIII&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Super Bowl XLVIII (page does not exist)">Super Bowl XLVIII</a> in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[261]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Rangers" title="New York Rangers">New York Rangers</a> represent the city in the National Hockey League.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[262]</a></sup>  The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Islanders" title="New York Islanders">New York Islanders</a>, who currently play in <a href="/wiki/Nassau_County,_New_York" title="Nassau County, New York">Nassau County</a> on <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[263]</a></sup> will become the second team in the city after their move to Brooklyn in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[264]</a></sup>
Also within the metropolitan area are the <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Devils" title="New Jersey Devils">New Jersey Devils</a>, who play in nearby <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark, New Jersey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city's National Basketball Association teams include the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Nets" title="Brooklyn Nets">Brooklyn Nets</a> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Knicks" title="New York Knicks">New York Knicks</a>, while the city's <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association" title="Women's National Basketball Association">Women's National Basketball Association</a> team is the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Liberty" title="New York Liberty">New York Liberty</a>. The first national college-level basketball championship, the <a href="/wiki/National_Invitation_Tournament" title="National Invitation Tournament">National Invitation Tournament</a>, was held in New York in 1938 and remains in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup>
</p><p>In soccer, New York is represented by the <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Soccer" title="Major League Soccer">Major League Soccer</a> side, <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_Red_Bulls&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York Red Bulls (page does not exist)">New York Red Bulls</a>. The Red Bulls play their home games at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Red_Bull_Arena_(Harrison)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Red Bull Arena (Harrison) (page does not exist)">Red Bull Arena</a> in nearby <a href="/wiki/Harrison,_New_Jersey" title="Harrison, New Jersey">Harrison, New Jersey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[267]</a></sup> The New York area's second Major League Soccer club, to be called <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_City_FC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York City FC (page does not exist)">New York City FC</a>, is planned to start play in the 2015 season, to be majority-owned by <a href="/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C." title="Manchester City F.C.">Manchester City F.C.</a> owner Sheikh <a href="/wiki/Mansour_bin_Zayed_Al_Nahyan" title="Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan">Mansour bin Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abu_Dhabi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abu Dhabi (page does not exist)">Abu Dhabi</a>, partnering with the New York Yankees baseball organization.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[268]</a></sup>
</p><p>Queens is host of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">U.S. Open Tennis Championships</a>, one of the four annual <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> tournaments.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[269]</a></sup>  The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Marathon" title="New York City Marathon">New York Marathon</a> is one of the world's largest, and the 2004–2006 events hold the top three places in the marathons with the largest number of finishers, including 37,866 finishers in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-World.27s_Largest_Marathons_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World.27s_Largest_Marathons-271">[270]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Millrose_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Millrose Games (page does not exist)">Millrose Games</a> is an annual track and field meet whose featured event is the <a href="/wiki/Wanamaker_Mile" title="Wanamaker Mile">Wanamaker Mile</a>. Boxing is also a prominent part of the city's sporting scene, with events like the Amateur Boxing Golden Gloves being held at <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a> each year.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[271]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many sports are associated with New York's immigrant communities. <a href="/wiki/Stickball" title="Stickball">Stickball</a>, a street version of baseball, was popularized by youths in the 1930s. A street in the Bronx has been renamed Stickball Blvd, as tribute to New York's most known street sport.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<table class="toc" style="float:right; font-size:90%; text-align:center; margin:1em;">

<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="background:tan;"><b>Top publicly traded companies<br /> in New York City for 2012</b><br /> (ranked by revenues)<br /><i>with City and U.S. ranks</i>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#ccc;">
<td> <b>NYC</b></td>
<td></td>
<td style="background:#ccc;"><b>corporation</b></td>
<td></td>
<td style="background:#ccc;"><b>US</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1</td>
<td></td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Verizon_Communications&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Verizon Communications (page does not exist)">Verizon Communications</a></td>
<td></td>
<td>16
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 2</td>
<td></td>

<td></td>
<td>18
</td></tr>
<tr>

</td></tr>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 5</td>
<td></td>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 6</td>

</td></tr>
<tr>

</td></tr>
<tr>

</td></tr>

<tr>
<td> 10</td>
<td></td>

</td></tr>
<tr>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 12</td>
<td></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/News_Corporation" title="News Corporation">News Corporation</a></td>
<td></td>
<td>91
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5" style="background:#afa;"><i>Financial services firms in green</i>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5">Full table at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_New_York_City&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economy of New York City (page does not exist)">Economy of New York City</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5"><b>Source:</b> <i>Fortune</i> 500<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[273]</a></sup>
</td></tr></table>
<p>New York is a <a href="/wiki/Global_city" title="Global city">global hub</a> of international business and commerce and is one of three "command centers" for the <a href="/wiki/World_economy" title="World economy">world economy</a> (along with London and <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[274]</a></sup> In 2012, New York City topped the first <i>Global Economic Power Index</i>, published by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Atlantic" title="The Atlantic">The Atlantic</a></i> (to be differentiated from a namesake list published by the <i>Martin Prosperity Institute</i>), with cities ranked according to criteria reflecting their presence on similar lists as published by other entities.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[275]</a></sup> The city is a major center for banking and finance, retailing, world trade, transportation, tourism, real estate, <a href="/wiki/New_media" title="New media">new media</a> as well as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Traditional_media&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Traditional media (page does not exist)">traditional media</a>, <a href="/wiki/Advertising" title="Advertising">advertising</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Legal_services&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Legal services (page does not exist)">legal services</a>, <a href="/wiki/Accountancy" title="Accountancy" class="mw-redirect">accountancy</a>, insurance, theater, fashion, and the arts in the United States.
</p><p>The New York <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_area" title="Metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a> had a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gross_metropolitan_product&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gross metropolitan product (page does not exist)">gross metropolitan product</a> (GMP) of approximately $1.28&#160;trillion in 2010,<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[276]</a></sup> making it the largest regional economy in the United States. According to <i>Cinco Dias</i>, New York controlled 40% of the world's finances by the end of 2008, making it the largest financial center in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-London_vs._New_York_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London_vs._New_York-278">[277]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-New_York_still_World.27s_Financal_Capital_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-New_York_still_World.27s_Financal_Capital-279">[278]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Is_New_York_still_the_World.27s_Financial_Capital_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Is_New_York_still_the_World.27s_Financial_Capital-280">[279]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg" title="File:Photos NewYork1 032.jpg">File:Photos NewYork1 032.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">New York Stock Exchange</a> on <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>, the world's largest stock exchange per total <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a> of its listed companies.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[280]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New York City has been ranked first among 120 cities across the globe in attracting <a href="/wiki/Capital_(economics)" title="Capital (economics)">capital</a>, business, and tourists.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup> In July 2012, the <a href="/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C." title="Manchester United F.C.">Manchester United Football Club</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> announced plans to list its <a href="/wiki/Initial_public_offering" title="Initial public offering">initial public offering</a> of stock shares on the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">New York Stock Exchange</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[282]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many major corporations are headquartered in New York City, including 45 <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> companies.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup> New York is also unique among American cities for its large number of foreign corporations. One out of ten private sector jobs in the city is with a foreign company.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[284]</a></sup> This ability to attract foreign investment helped New York City top the <a href="/w/index.php?title=FDi_Magazine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FDi Magazine (page does not exist)">FDi Magazine</a> American Cities of the Future ranking for 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[285]</a></sup>
</p><p>Real estate is a major force in the city's economy, as the total value of all New York City property was assessed at $914.8 billion for the 2015 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fiscal_year&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fiscal year (page does not exist)">fiscal year</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_real_estate_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_real_estate-287">[286]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Time_Warner_Center" title="Time Warner Center">Time Warner Center</a> is the property with the highest-listed market value in the city, at $1.1&#160;billion in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_real_estate_287-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_real_estate-287">[286]</a></sup> New York City is home to some of the nation's—and the world's—most valuable real estate. 450 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Park_Avenue_(Manhattan)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Park Avenue (Manhattan) (page does not exist)">Park Avenue</a> was sold on July 2, 2007 for $510&#160;million, about $1,589 per square foot ($17,104/m²), breaking the barely month-old record for an American office building of $1,476 per square foot ($15,887/m²) set in the June 2007 sale of 660 Madison Avenue.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[287]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city's television and film industry is the second largest in the country after <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[288]</a></sup> Creative industries such as new media, advertising, fashion, design and architecture account for a growing share of employment, with New York City possessing a strong competitive advantage in these industries.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[289]</a></sup>
</p><p>High-tech industries like <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Software_development" title="Software development">software development</a>, <a href="/wiki/Game_design" title="Game design">game design</a>, and internet services are also growing, bolstered by the city's position at the terminus of several <a href="/w/index.php?title=Transatlantic_telephone_cable&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Transatlantic telephone cable (page does not exist)">transatlantic fiber optic trunk lines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[290]</a></sup> Other important sectors include medical research and technology, <a href="/wiki/Non-profit" title="Non-profit" class="mw-redirect">non-profit</a> institutions, and universities. Manufacturing accounts for a large but declining share of employment. Garments, chemicals, metal products, processed foods, and furniture are some of the principal products.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[291]</a></sup> The food-processing industry is the most stable major manufacturing sector in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-food_manufacturing_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-food_manufacturing-293">[292]</a></sup> Food making is a $5&#160;billion industry that employs more than 19,000 residents. Chocolate is New York City's leading specialty-food export, with $234&#160;million worth of exports each year.<sup id="cite_ref-food_manufacturing_293-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-food_manufacturing-293">[292]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wall_Street">Wall Street</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> had approximately 520 million square feet (48.1 million m²) of office space in 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[293]</a></sup> making it the largest office market in the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[294]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown Manhattan</a> is the largest <a href="/wiki/Central_business_district" title="Central business district">central business district</a> in the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[295]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a> is the third largest central business district in the United States and is home to the New York Stock Exchange, on Wall Street, and the <a href="/wiki/NASDAQ" title="NASDAQ">NASDAQ</a>, representing the world's largest and second largest <a href="/wiki/Stock_exchange" title="Stock exchange">stock exchanges</a>, respectively, when measured by average daily trading volume and overall <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[296]</a></sup> Financial services account for more than 35% of the city's employment income.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[297]</a></sup> Wall Street <a href="/wiki/Investment_banking" title="Investment banking">investment banking</a> fees in 2012 totaled approximately $40 billion,<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup> while in 2013, senior New York City bank officers who manage <a href="/wiki/Risk_management" title="Risk management">risk and compliance</a> functions earned as much as US$324,000 annually.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[299]</a></sup>
</p><p>The financial district has sometimes been a scene of conflict such as with the recurrent protests during "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Occupy_Wall_Street&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Occupy Wall Street (page does not exist)">Occupy Wall Street</a>", which subsequently sparked an international <a href="/w/index.php?title=Occupy_Movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Occupy Movement (page does not exist)">Occupy Movement</a>. It has also sometimes turned deadly such as with the <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street_bombing" title="Wall Street bombing">Wall Street bombing</a> in 1929.
</p><p>In July 2013, <a href="/w/index.php?title=NYSE_Euronext&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NYSE Euronext (page does not exist)">NYSE Euronext</a>, the operator of the New York Stock Exchange, took over the administration of the <a href="/wiki/London_interbank_offered_rate" title="London interbank offered rate" class="mw-redirect">London interbank offered rate</a> from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Bankers_Association&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Bankers Association (page does not exist)">British Bankers Association</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[300]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_government">Law and government</span></h2>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:right; width:auto; font-size:90%; margin-left:1em;">

<td style="text-align:right; background:#b0ceff;"> <i>1,458,784</i>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Party_shading/Republican&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Party shading/Republican (page does not exist)">Template:Party shading/Republican</a> | 24.00%
</td>
<td style="text-align:right; background:#ffb6b6;"> <i>509,423</i>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 0.25em; background-color: #3333FF">

</td>

</th>

<tr>

</td>
<td style="text-align:right; background:#b0ceff;"> <i>2,183,646</i>
</td>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 0.25em; background-color: #3333FF">
</td>
<th> <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1960" title="United States presidential election, 1960">1960</a>
</th>

</td>
<td style="text-align:right; background:#b0ceff;"> <i>1,936,323</i>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Party_shading/Republican&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Party shading/Republican (page does not exist)">Template:Party shading/Republican</a> | 37.04%
</td>
<td style="text-align:right; background:#ffb6b6;"> <i>1,145,205</i>
</td></tr></table>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Municipal_Building_-_New_York_City.jpg" title="File:Municipal Building - New York City.jpg">File:Municipal Building - New York City.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Manhattan_Municipal_Building&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Manhattan Municipal Building (page does not exist)">Manhattan Municipal Building</a> is home to many city agencies.</div></div></div>
<p>New York City has been a <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_municipality" title="Metropolitan municipality">metropolitan municipality</a> with a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mayor%E2%80%93council_government&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mayor–council government (page does not exist)">mayor-council form of government</a><sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[302]</a></sup> since its consolidation in 1898. The government of New York is more centralized than that of most other U.S. cities. In New York City, the central government is responsible for public education, correctional institutions, libraries, public safety, recreational facilities, sanitation, water supply and welfare services. The <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_New_York_City" title="Mayor of New York City">mayor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Councilor" title="Councilor" class="mw-redirect">councilors</a> are elected to four-year terms. The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Council" title="New York City Council">New York City Council</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral</a> body consisting of 51 Council members whose districts are defined by geographic population boundaries.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[303]</a></sup> The mayor and councilors are limited to three consecutive four-year terms<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[304]</a></sup> but can run again after a four-year break.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:New_York_City_Hall.jpg" title="File:New York City Hall.jpg">File:New York City Hall.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Hall" title="New York City Hall">New York City Hall</a> is the oldest City Hall in the United States that still houses its original governmental functions.</div></div></div>
<p>The present mayor is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bill_de_Blasio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bill de Blasio (page does not exist)">Bill de Blasio</a>, a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democrat</a><sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[305]</a></sup> who assumed office on January 1, 2014. Each mayoral term lasts four years, with a three <a href="/wiki/Term_limit" title="Term limit">consecutive-term limit</a>.
</p><p>The Democratic Party holds the majority of public offices. As of November 2008, 67% of registered voters in the city are Democrats.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup> New York City has not been carried by a Republican in a statewide or presidential election since 1924. <a href="/wiki/Party_platform" title="Party platform">Party platforms</a> center on affordable housing, education and economic development, and labor politics are of importance in the city.
</p><p>Following a financial crisis and state <a href="/wiki/Bailout" title="Bailout">bailout</a> in 1975, the New York <a href="/wiki/Board_of_Control_(municipal_government)" title="Board of Control (municipal government)">Financial Control Board</a> was created to oversee municipal spending. The Mayor of New York City and the Governor of New York both serve on the seven-member board.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[307]</a></sup> While direct management of the city's budget ended in 1986, the board continues to monitor the city's financial health.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[308]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York is the most important source of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Political_fundraising&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Political fundraising (page does not exist)">political fundraising</a> in the United States, as four of the top five <a href="/wiki/ZIP_code" title="ZIP code">ZIP codes</a> in the nation for political contributions are in Manhattan. The top zip code, 10021 on the <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Side" title="Upper East Side">Upper East Side</a>, generated the most money for the 2004 presidential campaigns of <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_W._Bush&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George W. Bush (page does not exist)">George W. Bush</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Kerry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Kerry (page does not exist)">John Kerry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[309]</a></sup> The city has a strong imbalance of payments with the national and state governments. It receives 83 cents in services for every $1 it sends to the federal government in <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_the_United_States" title="Taxation in the United States">taxes</a> (or annually sends $11.4&#160;billion more than it receives back). The city also sends an additional $11&#160;billion more each year to the state of New York than it receives back.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[310]</a></sup>
</p><p>Each borough is coextensive with a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Judicial_district&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Judicial district (page does not exist)">judicial district</a> of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court" title="New York Supreme Court">New York Supreme Court</a> and hosts other state and city courts. Manhattan also hosts the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court,_Appellate_Division" title="New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division">Supreme Court Appellate Division, First Department</a>, while Brooklyn hosts the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court,_Appellate_Division" title="New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division">Appellate Division, Second Department</a>. Uniquely among major American cities, New York is divided between, and is host to the main branches of, two different <a href="/wiki/United_States_District_Court" title="United States District Court" class="mw-redirect">United States District Courts</a>: the <a href="/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Southern_District_of_New_York" title="United States District Court for the Southern District of New York">United States District Court for the Southern District of New York</a>, whose main courthouse is on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Foley_Square&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Foley Square (page does not exist)">Foley Square</a> near City Hall in Manhattan and whose jurisdiction includes Manhattan and the Bronx, and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Eastern_District_of_New_York" title="United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York">United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York</a>, whose main courthouse is in Brooklyn and whose jurisdiction includes Brooklyn, Queens, and Staten Island. The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Court_of_Appeals_for_the_Second_Circuit" title="United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit">United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_States_Court_of_International_Trade" title="United States Court of International Trade">United States Court of International Trade</a> are also based in New York, also on Foley Square in Manhattan.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_issues">Environmental issues</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Mass transit use in New York City is the highest in the United States, and gasoline consumption in the city is the same rate as the national average in the 1920s.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_energy_consumption_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_energy_consumption-312">[311]</a></sup> The city's high level of mass transit use saved <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of oil in 2006; New York City saves half of all the oil saved by transit nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[312]</a></sup> The city's population density, low automobile use and high transit utility make it among the most energy efficient cities in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[313]</a></sup> Its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas (page does not exist)">greenhouse gas</a> emissions are 7.1 <a href="/wiki/Metric_ton" title="Metric ton" class="mw-redirect">metric tons</a> per person compared with the national average of 24.5.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_emissions_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_emissions-315">[314]</a></sup> New Yorkers are collectively responsible for 1% of the nation's greenhouse gas emissions<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_emissions_315-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_emissions-315">[314]</a></sup> though they comprise 2.7% of the nation's population. The average New Yorker consumes less than half the electricity used by a resident of San Francisco and nearly one-quarter the electricity consumed by a resident of <a href="/wiki/Dallas" title="Dallas">Dallas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[315]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG" title="File:NYC Hybrid Taxi.JPG">File:NYC Hybrid Taxi.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">As of July 2010 the city had 3,715 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hybrid_taxi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hybrid taxi (page does not exist)">hybrid taxis</a> in service, the largest number in any city in North America.</div></div></div>
<p>In recent years, the city has focused on reducing its <a href="/wiki/Human_impact_on_the_environment" title="Human impact on the environment">environmental impact</a>. Large amounts of concentrated pollution in New York has led to a high incidence of <a href="/wiki/Asthma" title="Asthma">asthma</a> and other respiratory conditions among the city's residents.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[316]</a></sup> The city government is required to purchase only the most energy-efficient equipment for use in city offices and public housing.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[317]</a></sup> New York has the largest clean air diesel-<a href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle" title="Hybrid vehicle">hybrid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Compressed_natural_gas" title="Compressed natural gas">compressed natural gas</a> bus fleet in the country,<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[318]</a></sup> and also, by mid-2010 the city had 3,715 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hybrid_electric_vehicle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hybrid electric vehicle (page does not exist)">hybrid</a> taxis and other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Clean_diesel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Clean diesel (page does not exist)">clean diesel</a> vehicles, representing around 28% of New York's taxi fleet in service, the most in any city in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT072710_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT072710-320">[319]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city government was a petitioner in the landmark <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Massachusetts_v._Environmental_Protection_Agency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Massachusetts v. Environmental Protection Agency (page does not exist)">Massachusetts v. Environmental Protection Agency</a></i> Supreme Court case forcing the EPA to regulate greenhouse gases as pollutants. The city is also a leader in the construction of energy-efficient <a href="/wiki/Green_building" title="Green building">green office buildings</a>, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hearst_Tower_(New_York_City)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hearst Tower (New York City) (page does not exist)">Hearst Tower</a> among others.<sup id="cite_ref-greenbuilding_169-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-greenbuilding-169">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city is supplied with drinking water by the protected <a href="/wiki/Catskill_Mountains" title="Catskill Mountains">Catskill Mountains</a> <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">watershed</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[320]</a></sup> As a result of the watershed's integrity and undisturbed natural water filtration system, New York is one of only four major cities in the United States with drinking water pure enough not to require purification by <a href="/wiki/Water_treatment" title="Water treatment">water treatment</a> plants.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[321]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York is the only US city in which a majority (52%) of households do not have a car; only 22% of Manhattanites own a car.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[322]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Crime">Crime</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chevrolet_Volt_NYPD_--_04-04-2012.JPG" title="File:Chevrolet Volt NYPD -- 04-04-2012.JPG">File:Chevrolet Volt NYPD -- 04-04-2012.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">NYPD traffic enforcement cruiser</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Police_Department" title="New York Police Department" class="mw-redirect">New York Police Department</a> (NYPD) has been the largest in the United States by a significant margin, with over 35,000 sworn officers.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[323]</a></sup> In 2012, New York City had the lowest overall <a href="/wiki/Crime_rate" title="Crime rate" class="mw-redirect">crime rate</a> and the second lowest murder rate among the largest U.S. cities,<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[324]</a></sup> having become significantly safer after a spike in crime in the 1980s<sup id="cite_ref-Prager_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Prager-326">[325]</a></sup> and early 1990s. By 2002, New York City's crime rate was similar to that of <a href="/wiki/Provo,_Utah" title="Provo, Utah">Provo, Utah</a> and was ranked 197th in crime among the 216 U.S. cities with populations greater than 100,000.<sup id="cite_ref-Law_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Law-327">[326]</a></sup>
</p><p>Violent crime in New York City decreased more than 75% from 1993 to 2005, and continued decreasing during periods when the nation as a whole saw increases.<sup id="cite_ref-Law_327-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Law-327">[326]</a></sup> In 2005 the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_homicide_rate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by homicide rate (page does not exist)">homicide rate</a> was at its lowest level since 1966,<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[327]</a></sup> and in 2007 the city recorded fewer than 500 <a href="/wiki/Homicide" title="Homicide">homicides</a> for the first time ever since crime statistics were first published in 1963.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[328]</a></sup> In the first six months of 2010, 95.1% of all murder victims and 95.9% of all shooting victims in New York City were black or Hispanic; additionally, 90.2 percent of those arrested for murder and 96.7 percent of those arrested for shooting someone were black or Hispanic.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[329]</a></sup> New York experienced a record low homicide rate in 2013 and has a far lower murder rate than other major American cities.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[330]</a></sup> In 2012 the NYPD came under scrutiny for its use of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_City_stop-and-frisk_program&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York City stop-and-frisk program (page does not exist)">stop-and-frisk</a> program.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[331]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[332]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[333]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sociologists and criminologists have not reached consensus on what explains the dramatic decrease in the city's crime rate. Some attribute the phenomenon to new tactics used by the NYPD,<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[334]</a></sup> including its use of <a href="/wiki/CompStat" title="CompStat">CompStat</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Broken_windows_theory" title="Broken windows theory">broken windows theory</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[335]</a></sup> Others cite the end of the crack epidemic and demographic changes.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[336]</a></sup> Another theory is that widespread exposure to lead pollution from automobile exhaust, which can lower intelligence and increase aggression levels, incited the initial crime wave in the mid-20th century, most acutely affecting heavily trafficked cities like New York. A strong correlation was found demonstrating that violent crime rates in New York and other big cities began to fall after lead was removed from American gasoline in the 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[337]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Organized_crime" title="Organized crime">Organized crime</a> has long been associated with New York City, beginning with the <a href="/wiki/Forty_Thieves_(New_York_gang)" title="Forty Thieves (New York gang)">Forty Thieves</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Roach_Guards" title="Roach Guards">Roach Guards</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Five_Points,_Manhattan" title="Five Points, Manhattan">Five Points</a> in the 1820s. The 20th century saw a rise in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Mafia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Mafia (page does not exist)">Mafia</a> dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Five_Families" title="Five Families">Five Families</a> and they are still the largest and most powerful criminal organization in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[338]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gang" title="Gang">Gangs</a> including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Black_Spades&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Black Spades (page does not exist)">Black Spades</a> also grew in the late 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[339]</a></sup> As early as 1850, New York City recorded more than 200 gang wars fought largely by youth gangs.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[340]</a></sup> The most prominent gangs in New York City today are the <a href="/wiki/Bloods" title="Bloods">Bloods</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crips&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crips (page does not exist)">Crips</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latin_Kings_(gang)" title="Latin Kings (gang)">Latin Kings</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=MS-13&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MS-13 (page does not exist)">MS-13</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[341]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Low_Library_Columbia_University_8-11-06.jpg" title="File:Low Library Columbia University 8-11-06.jpg">File:Low Library Columbia University 8-11-06.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a>'s Low Memorial Library</div></div></div>
<p>The city's public school system, managed by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_City_Department_of_Education&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York City Department of Education (page does not exist)">New York City Department of Education</a>, is the largest in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[342]</a></sup> About 1.1&#160;million students are taught in more than 1,200 separate primary and secondary schools.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[343]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charter_school&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charter school (page does not exist)">Charter schools</a>, which are partly publicly funded, include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Success_Academy_Charter_Schools&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Success Academy Charter Schools (page does not exist)">Success Academy Charter Schools</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_Prep&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public Prep (page does not exist)">Public Prep</a>. There are approximately 900 additional privately run secular and religious schools in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[344]</a></sup> About 594,000 students were enrolled as of the 2000 Census in New York City <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">higher education</a> institutions, the highest number of any city in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[345]</a></sup> In 2005, three out of five Manhattan residents were college graduates and one out of four had advanced degrees, forming one of the highest concentrations of highly educated people in any American city.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York City is home to such notable private universities as <a href="/wiki/Barnard_College" title="Barnard College">Barnard College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cooper_Union" title="Cooper Union">Cooper Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fordham_University" title="Fordham University">Fordham University</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York University (page does not exist)">New York University</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_Institute_of_Technology" title="New York Institute of Technology">New York Institute of Technology</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pace_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pace University (page does not exist)">Pace University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yeshiva_University" title="Yeshiva University">Yeshiva University</a>. The public <a href="/wiki/City_University_of_New_York" title="City University of New York">City University of New York</a> system is one of the largest universities in the nation, and includes a number of undergraduate colleges and associate degree <a href="/wiki/Community_college" title="Community college">community colleges</a>, with options in each borough. The city also has other smaller private colleges and universities, including many religious and special-purpose institutions, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=St._John%27s_University_(Jamaica,_NY)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="St. John's University (Jamaica, NY) (page does not exist)">St. John's University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juilliard_School" title="Juilliard School">The Juilliard School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_College" title="Manhattan College">Manhattan College</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=College_of_Mount_Saint_Vincent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="College of Mount Saint Vincent (page does not exist)">The College of Mount Saint Vincent</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_New_School" title="The New School">The New School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pratt_Institute" title="Pratt Institute">Pratt Institute</a>, <a href="/wiki/School_of_Visual_Arts" title="School of Visual Arts">The School of Visual Arts</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wagner_College" title="Wagner College">Wagner College</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fordham_University_Keating_Hall.JPG" title="File:Fordham University Keating Hall.JPG">File:Fordham University Keating Hall.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Fordham_University" title="Fordham University">Fordham University</a>'s Keating Hall in the Bronx</div></div></div>
<p>Much of the <a href="/wiki/Scientific_research" title="Scientific research" class="mw-redirect">scientific research</a> in the city is done in <a href="/wiki/Medicine" title="Medicine">medicine</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Life_sciences" title="Life sciences">life sciences</a>. New York City has the most post-graduate life sciences degrees awarded annually in the United States, 40,000 licensed physicians, and 127 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_laureate" title="Nobel laureate" class="mw-redirect">Nobel laureates</a> with roots in local institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_science_institutions_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_science_institutions-348">[347]</a></sup> The city receives the second-highest amount of annual funding from the <a href="/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health" title="National Institutes of Health">National Institutes of Health</a> among all U.S. cities.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[348]</a></sup> Major biomedical research institutions include <a href="/wiki/Memorial_Sloan%E2%80%93Kettering_Cancer_Center" title="Memorial Sloan–Kettering Cancer Center">Memorial Sloan–Kettering Cancer Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_University" title="Rockefeller University">Rockefeller University</a>, <a href="/wiki/SUNY_Downstate_Medical_Center" title="SUNY Downstate Medical Center">SUNY Downstate Medical Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein_College_of_Medicine" title="Albert Einstein College of Medicine">Albert Einstein College of Medicine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mount_Sinai_School_of_Medicine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mount Sinai School of Medicine (page does not exist)">Mount Sinai School of Medicine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Weill_Cornell_Medical_College_of_Cornell_University" title="Weill Cornell Medical College of Cornell University" class="mw-redirect">Weill Cornell Medical College</a>. On December 19, 2011, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his choice of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cornell_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cornell University (page does not exist)">Cornell University</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Technion-Israel_Institute_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Technion-Israel Institute of Technology (page does not exist)">Technion-Israel Institute of Technology</a> to build a $2 billion graduate school of <a href="/wiki/Applied_science" title="Applied science">applied sciences</a> on <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island" title="Roosevelt Island">Roosevelt Island</a>, with the goal of transforming New York City into the world's premier technology capital.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[349]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[350]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Public_Library" title="New York Public Library">New York Public Library</a>, which has the largest collection of any public library system in the country, serves Manhattan, the Bronx, and Staten Island.<sup id="cite_ref-libraryspot_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-libraryspot-352">[351]</a></sup> The New York Public Library has several research libraries, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Schomburg_Center_for_Research_in_Black_Culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture (page does not exist)">Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture</a>. Queens is served by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Queens_Borough_Public_Library&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Queens Borough Public Library (page does not exist)">Queens Borough Public Library</a>, which is the nation's second largest public library system. The <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Public_Library" title="Brooklyn Public Library">Brooklyn Public Library</a> serves Brooklyn.<sup id="cite_ref-libraryspot_352-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-libraryspot-352">[351]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg" title="File:Image-Grand central Station Outside Night 2.jpg">File:Image-Grand central Station Outside Night 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">New York City is home to the two busiest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Train_station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Train station (page does not exist)">rail stations</a> in the US, including <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Terminal" title="Grand Central Terminal">Grand Central Terminal</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Mass_transit_in_New_York_City" title="Mass transit in New York City">Mass transit in New York City</a>, most of which runs 24 hours a day, is the most complex and extensive in North America. About one in every three users of mass transit in the United States and two-thirds of the nation's rail riders live in the New York City Metropolitan Area.<sup id="cite_ref-MTAinfo_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MTAinfo-353">[352]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[353]</a></sup> The iconic <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">New York City Subway</a> system is <a href="/wiki/Metro_systems_by_annual_passenger_rides" title="Metro systems by annual passenger rides">the busiest in the Western Hemisphere</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Terminal" title="Grand Central Terminal">Grand Central Terminal</a>, also popularly referred to as "Grand Central Station", is the world's largest railway station by number of platforms. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aviation_in_the_New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aviation in the New York metropolitan area (page does not exist)">New York's airspace</a> is one of the world's busiest air transportation corridors. The <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Bridge" title="George Washington Bridge">George Washington Bridge</a>, connecting Manhattan to <a href="/wiki/Bergen_County,_New_Jersey" title="Bergen County, New Jersey">Bergen County, New Jersey</a>, is the world's busiest motor vehicle bridge.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[354]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[355]</a></sup>
</p><p>Public transit is popular in New York City. 54.6% of New Yorkers commuted to work in 2005 using mass transit.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[356]</a></sup> This is in contrast to the rest of the United States, where about 90% of commuters drive automobiles to their workplace.<sup id="cite_ref-2001summary_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2001summary-358">[357]</a></sup> According to the US Census Bureau, New York City residents spend an average of 38.4 minutes a day getting to work, the longest commute time in the nation among large cities.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[358]</a></sup> However, due to the high usage of mass transit, New Yorkers spend less of their household income on transportation than the national average. New Yorkers save $19 billion annually on transportation compared to other urban Americans.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[359]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg" title="File:NYC Subway R160A 9237 on the E.jpg">File:NYC Subway R160A 9237 on the E.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">New York City Subway</a> is the world's largest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rapid_transit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rapid transit (page does not exist)">rapid transit</a> system by length of routes and by number of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Train_station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Train station (page does not exist)">stations</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>New York City is served by <a href="/wiki/Amtrak" title="Amtrak">Amtrak</a>, which uses <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Station_(New_York_City)" title="Pennsylvania Station (New York City)">Pennsylvania Station</a>. Amtrak provides connections to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boston&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boston (page does not exist)">Boston</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Corridor" title="Northeast Corridor">Northeast Corridor</a> and long-distance train service to other <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North American</a> cities. The <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Bus_Terminal" title="Port Authority Bus Terminal">Port Authority Bus Terminal</a>, the main <a href="/w/index.php?title=Intercity_bus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Intercity bus (page does not exist)">intercity bus</a> terminal of the city, serves 7,000 buses and 200,000 commuters daily, making it the busiest bus station in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[360]</a></sup>
</p><p>The New York City Subway is the largest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rapid_transit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rapid transit (page does not exist)">rapid transit</a> system in the world when measured by stations in operation, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:NYCS_const&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:NYCS const (page does not exist)">Template:NYCS const</a>, and by length of routes. It is the third-largest when measured by annual ridership (1.5&#160;billion passenger trips in 2006).<sup id="cite_ref-MTAinfo_353-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MTAinfo-353">[352]</a></sup> New York's subway is also notable because nearly the entire system remains open 24 hours a day, in contrast to the overnight shutdown common to systems in most cities, including <a href="/wiki/MTR" title="MTR">Hong Kong</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[361]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[362]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris_M%C3%A9tro" title="Paris Métro">Paris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seoul_Metropolitan_Subway" title="Seoul Metropolitan Subway">Seoul</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[363]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[364]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tokyo_Subway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tokyo Subway (page does not exist)">Tokyo</a>.
</p><p>The city's complex and extensive transportation system also includes the longest <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">suspension bridge</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a> and one of the world's longest (the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Verrazano-Narrows Bridge (page does not exist)">Verrazano-Narrows</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-infoplease.com_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-infoplease.com-366">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge-367">[366]</a></sup> the world's first mechanically ventilated vehicular <a href="/wiki/Holland_Tunnel" title="Holland Tunnel">tunnel</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-nhlsum_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nhlsum-368">[367]</a></sup> more than 12,000 <a href="/wiki/Taxicabs_of_New_York_City" title="Taxicabs of New York City">yellow cabs</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[368]</a></sup> an <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island_Tramway" title="Roosevelt Island Tramway">aerial tramway</a> that transports commuters between <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island" title="Roosevelt Island">Roosevelt Island</a> and Manhattan Island, and a ferry system connecting Manhattan to various locales within and outside the city.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg" title="File:JFK Plane Queue.jpg">File:JFK Plane Queue.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">As of 2011, <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">JFK International Airport</a> in <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">Queens</a> was the <a href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_international_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by international passenger traffic">busiest airport for international passengers</a> in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[369]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The busiest ferry in the United States is the <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry" title="Staten Island Ferry">Staten Island Ferry</a>, which annually carries approximately 20 million passengers on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> run between Staten Island and Lower Manhattan.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[370]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Railway" title="Staten Island Railway">Staten Island Railway</a> rapid transit system solely serves Staten Island. The <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Trans-Hudson" title="Port Authority Trans-Hudson">Port Authority Trans-Hudson</a> ("PATH" train) links Midtown and Lower Manhattan to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northeastern_New_Jersey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northeastern New Jersey (page does not exist)">northeastern New Jersey</a>, primarily <a href="/wiki/Hoboken,_New_Jersey" title="Hoboken, New Jersey">Hoboken</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jersey_City,_New_Jersey" title="Jersey City, New Jersey">Jersey City</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark</a>. Like the New York City Subway, the PATH operates 24 hours a day; meaning two of the four rapid transit systems in the world which operate on 24-hour schedules are wholly or partly in New York (the others are a portion of the <a href="/wiki/Chicago_%27L%27" title="Chicago 'L'">Chicago 'L'</a> and the <a href="/wiki/PATCO_Speedline" title="PATCO Speedline">PATCO Speedline</a> serving Philadelphia).
</p><p>New York City's public <a href="/w/index.php?title=MTA_Regional_Bus_Operations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MTA Regional Bus Operations (page does not exist)">bus fleet</a> and commuter rail network are the largest in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-MTAinfo_353-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MTAinfo-353">[352]</a></sup> The rail network, connecting the suburbs in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tri-State_Region&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tri-State Region (page does not exist)">tri-state region</a> to the city, consists of the <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_Rail_Road" title="Long Island Rail Road">Long Island Rail Road</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metro-North_Railroad" title="Metro-North Railroad">Metro-North Railroad</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Jersey_Transit_rail_operations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Jersey Transit rail operations (page does not exist)">New Jersey Transit</a>. The combined systems converge at <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Terminal" title="Grand Central Terminal">Grand Central Terminal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Station_(New_York_City)" title="Pennsylvania Station (New York City)">Pennsylvania Station</a> and contain more than 250 stations and 20 rail lines.<sup id="cite_ref-MTAinfo_353-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MTAinfo-353">[352]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[371]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York City is the top international air passenger gateway to the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-IntlTravel_373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IntlTravel-373">[372]</a></sup> The area is served by three major airports, <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy International</a>, <a href="/wiki/Newark_Liberty_International_Airport" title="Newark Liberty International Airport">Newark Liberty International</a>, and <a href="/wiki/LaGuardia_Airport" title="LaGuardia Airport">LaGuardia</a>; 100 million travelers used the three airports in 2005, and the city's airspace is the busiest in the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[373]</a></sup> Outbound international travel from JFK and Newark accounted for about a quarter of all U.S. travelers who went overseas in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[374]</a></sup> Plans have advanced to expand passenger volume at a fourth airport, <a href="/wiki/Stewart_International_Airport" title="Stewart International Airport">Stewart International Airport</a> near <a href="/w/index.php?title=Newburgh,_New_York&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Newburgh, New York (page does not exist)">Newburgh, New York</a>, by the <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey" title="Port Authority of New York and New Jersey">Port Authority of New York and New Jersey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[375]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Verrazano.jpg" title="File:Verrazano.jpg">File:Verrazano.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Verrazano-Narrows Bridge (page does not exist)">Verrazano-Narrows Bridge</a>, one of the world's longest <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">suspension bridges</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-infoplease.com_366-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-infoplease.com-366">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_367-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge-367">[366]</a></sup> connects <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a> across <a href="/wiki/The_Narrows" title="The Narrows">The Narrows</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>New York's high rate of <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._cities_with_high_transit_ridership&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of U.S. cities with high transit ridership (page does not exist)">public transit use</a>, 120,000 daily cyclists,<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[376]</a></sup> and many <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._cities_with_most_pedestrian_commuters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of U.S. cities with most pedestrian commuters (page does not exist)">pedestrian commuters</a> make it the most energy-efficient major city in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-NYC_energy_consumption_312-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_energy_consumption-312">[311]</a></sup> Walk and bicycle modes of travel account for 21% of all modes for trips in the city; nationally the rate for metro regions is about 8%.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[377]</a></sup> In 2011, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walk_Score&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Walk Score (page does not exist)">Walk Score</a> named it the most walkable city in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[378]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[379]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Citibank" title="Citibank">Citibank</a> sponsored the introduction of 10,000 public bicycles for the city's bike-share project in the summer of 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[380]</a></sup> Research conducted by Quinnipiac University showed that a majority of New Yorkers support the initiative.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[381]</a></sup>
</p><p>To complement New York's vast mass transit network, the city also has an extensive web of <a href="/wiki/Freeway" title="Freeway" class="mw-redirect">expressways</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parkway" title="Parkway">parkways</a>, that link New York City to <a href="/wiki/North_Jersey" title="North Jersey">northern New Jersey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Westchester_County,_New_York" title="Westchester County, New York">Westchester County</a>, <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>, and southwestern <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">Connecticut</a> through various <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bridges_and_tunnels_in_New_York_City&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bridges and tunnels in New York City (page does not exist)">bridges and tunnels</a>. Because these highways serve millions of suburban residents who <a href="/wiki/Commuting" title="Commuting">commute</a> into New York City, it is quite common for motorists to be stranded for hours in <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">traffic jams</a> that are a daily occurrence, particularly during <a href="/wiki/Rush_hour" title="Rush hour">rush hour</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-recordonline.com_383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-recordonline.com-383">[382]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite New York's reliance on public transit, roads are a defining feature of the city. <a href="/wiki/Commissioners%27_Plan_of_1811" title="Commissioners' Plan of 1811">Manhattan's street grid plan</a> greatly influenced the city's physical development. Several of the city's streets and avenues, like <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(New_York_City)" title="Broadway (New York City)">Broadway</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[383]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[384]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Madison_Avenue_(Manhattan)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Madison Avenue (Manhattan) (page does not exist)">Madison Avenue</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[385]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[386]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Seventh_Avenue_(Manhattan)" title="Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)">Seventh Avenue</a> are also used as <a href="/wiki/Metonymy" title="Metonymy">metonyms</a> for national industries there: the theater, finance, advertising, and fashion organizations, respectively.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h2>
<p>New York City is home to <a href="/wiki/Fort_Hamilton" title="Fort Hamilton">Fort Hamilton</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">U.S. military's</a> only active duty installation within the city.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[387]</a></sup> Established in 1825 in Brooklyn on the site of a small battery utilized during the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>, it is one of America's longest serving military forts.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[388]</a></sup> Today Fort Hamilton serves as the headquarters of the North Atlantic Division, <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army_Corps_of_Engineers" title="United States Army Corps of Engineers">United States Army Corps of Engineers</a>, as well as the New York City Recruiting Battalion. It also houses the 1179th Transportation Brigade, the 722nd Aeromedical Staging Squadron, and a Military Entrance Processing Station.
</p><p>Other formerly active military reservations still utilized for military training or reserve and <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_National_Guard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States National Guard (page does not exist)">National Guard</a> operations in the city include <a href="/wiki/Fort_Wadsworth" title="Fort Wadsworth">Fort Wadsworth</a> in Staten Island and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Totten_(New_York)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Totten (New York) (page does not exist)">Fort Totten</a> in Queens.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Global_outreach">Global outreach</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historic_sister_cities">Historic sister cities</span></h3>
<p>New York City has eleven historic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Town_twinning&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Town twinning (page does not exist)">sister cities</a>:<sup id="cite_ref-GlobalOutreach_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GlobalOutreach-390">[389]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable">

<tr>
<th> City
</th>
<th> Since
</th></tr>

<td> 1960

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="New_York_City_Global_Partners_network">New York City Global Partners network</span></h3>
<p>In 2006, the Sister City Program of the City of New York, Inc. was restructured and renamed <i>New York City Global Partners</i>. New York City has expanded its international outreach via this program to a network of cities worldwide, promoting the exchange of ideas and <a href="/wiki/Innovation" title="Innovation">innovation</a> between their citizenry and policymakers, according to the city's website. The list of historic sister cities above was consolidated into the Global Partners network and joined by the cities below,<sup id="cite_ref-GlobalOutreach_390-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GlobalOutreach-390">[389]</a></sup> including <a href="/wiki/Chongqing" title="Chongqing">Chongqing</a> (Chungking), <a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur" title="Kuala Lumpur">Kuala Lumpur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a> (four "non-historic" sister cities of New York).
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Collapse_top&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Collapse top (page does not exist)">Template:Collapse top</a>
</p><p><b>Africa/Middle East</b>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col (page does not exist)">Template:Div col</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Accra" title="Accra">Accra</a>, Ghana
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, Ethiopia
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">Cape Town</a>, South Africa
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Dubai" title="Dubai">Dubai</a>, United Arab Emirates
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Istanbul&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Istanbul (page does not exist)">Istanbul</a>, Turkey
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Lagos" title="Lagos">Lagos</a>, Nigeria
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Nairobi" title="Nairobi">Nairobi</a>, Kenya
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a>, Israel<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[393]</a></sup>

</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col_end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col end (page does not exist)">Template:Div col end</a>

<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <a href="/wiki/File:Wikiversity-logo-Snorky.svg" title="File:Wikiversity-logo-Snorky.svg">Search Wikiversity</a>
   <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=V:Special:Search/New_York_City&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="V:Special:Search/New York City (page does not exist)">Learning resources</a> from Wikiversity






</table>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nyc.gov/">NYC.gov</a>—official website of New York City.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://nycvisit.com/">NYCvisit.com</a>—official tourism website of New York City.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Osmrelation-inline&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Osmrelation-inline (page does not exist)">Template:Osmrelation-inline</a>.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.beautyofnyc.org/">BeautyOfNYC</a> explains the beauty of New York City through landmarks, art, and poetry.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Dmoz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Dmoz (page does not exist)">Template:Dmoz</a>.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://collections.mcny.org/MCNY/C.aspx?VP3=CMS3&amp;VF=MNY_HomePage#/CMS3&amp;VF=MNY_HomePage">More than 62,000 historic photographs</a> of New York City are available online through the Museum of the City of New York.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://thecityreview.com/home.html">The City Guide</a> has many articles on New York City and historical architectural information by Carter B. Horsley, writer for <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Sun" title="The New York Sun">The New York Sun</a></i> newspaper.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.pbs.org/wnet/newyork/"><i>New York: A Documentary Film</i></a> directed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ric_Burns&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ric Burns (page does not exist)">Ric Burns</a> is a cinematic history of the city from its beginnings through 2003.
</li>
</ul>

											<li id="footer-places-privacy"><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia_clone:Privacy_policy" title="Wikipedia clone:Privacy policy">Privacy policy</a></li>
											<li id="footer-places-about"><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia_clone:About" title="Wikipedia clone:About">About Wikipedia</a></li>
											<li id="footer-places-disclaimer"><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_disclaimer" title="wikipedia:General disclaimer">Disclaimers</a></li>
									</ul>
										<ul id="footer-icons" class="noprint">
					<li id="footer-poweredbyico">
						<a href="//www.mediawiki.org/"><img src="/w/skins/common/images/poweredby_mediawiki_88x31.png" alt="Powered by MediaWiki" width="88" height="31" /></a>
					</li>
				</ul>
						<div style="clear:both"></div>
		</div>

}</script>
